Source Books

What Are These Item Types?

Coaching Move

A specific tactic, technique, or instinct Ali can apply during a coaching conversation. Think of it as a tool in Ali's belt — something actionable Ali can recommend or deploy when the right situation arises.

Aligned example: "Context Before Strategy" — Ali always establishes the negotiation type, phase, forces, and alternatives before offering tactical advice.

Framework

A mental model or structured way of thinking about a negotiation problem. Frameworks help Ali organize the user's situation and guide them through a decision process.

Aligned example: "The Four Types" — Every negotiation is classified as Bargaining, Trading, Creating, or Partnering. The type determines Ali's coaching approach.

Example

A real-world case study or story that illustrates a principle. Ali uses examples to ground abstract advice in concrete scenarios the user can relate to.

Aligned example: The "Brake Rotors" scenario — Mark's test case where Ali incorrectly revealed the rotors were from a canceled order (a leverage tell).

Quote

A memorable, quotable line that captures a key insight. Ali can reference these to reinforce coaching points with the authority of published experts.

Aligned example: Mark's "99.9% of the time we ask some form of those four questions" — grounds the diagnostic question requirement in real coaching practice.

How This Improves Ali's Conversations

Here's a concrete example. Today, when a user asks Ali about handling a tough counterpart, Ali draws only from Aligned's methodology. With book knowledge approved, Ali can blend Aligned's framework with published expertise:

Example Coaching Conversation — With Book Knowledge
User
The supplier keeps stone-walling me. I present my proposal and they just say "no, that doesn't work for us" without explaining why. I'm stuck.
Ali
That's a common pattern in positional bargaining — they're holding a position without revealing their interests. Let me ask: what's the relationship like? Is this a one-time deal or an ongoing partnership?
Aligned framework: Four Diagnostic Questions (Mark's required intake) + Negotiation Type classification
User
It's a long-term supplier. We've worked together for 3 years but this contract renewal is getting adversarial.
Ali
OK, this sounds like it's shifted from a Partnering dynamic to Trading. When they stone-wall, try this: instead of restating your proposal, ask a calibrated question like "How am I supposed to make this work within our budget constraints?" This puts the problem back on their side to solve, without being confrontational.
Book knowledge (Voss): Calibrated Questions coaching move — "How" questions that make counterparts feel in control while solving your problems.
Ali
And rather than negotiating on their terms, consider whether you can change the structure of the deal itself. Are there terms you could add or remove that would create value for both sides? Sometimes the most powerful move isn't at the table — it's redesigning what's on it.
Book knowledge (Fisher/Ury): "Invent Options for Mutual Gain" — broaden options before deciding, look for mutual gains.

Notice how Ali weaves Aligned's diagnostic approach with book-sourced tactics. The approved items below make this possible.

Getting to Yes Integrative / Harvard

Roger Fisher, William Ury, Bruce Patton (1981)
The foundational text of integrative negotiation from the Harvard Negotiation Project. Fisher, Ury, and Patton argue that most negotiations fail because people bargain over positions — making demands and counter-demands — when they should be solving problems together. Their alternative: principled negotiation, built on four pillars: separate people from the problem, focus on interests not positions, invent options for mutual gain, and insist on objective criteria.

Introduction

17 items
Frames the core problem: everyone negotiates — with bosses, landlords, spouses, children — but most do it poorly. Positional bargaining (the instinct to stake out a position and defend it) produces unwise agreements, wastes time, and endangers ongoing relationships. Introduces the method of 'principled negotiation' developed at the Harvard Negotiation Project as a practical alternative.
Coaching Move × 6 Framework × 5 Example × 1 Quote × 5
Framework Two Standard Negotiation Approaches
The soft negotiator prioritizes avoiding conflict and readily makes concessions, often ending up exploited and bitter. The hard negotiator treats negotiation as a contest of wills, taking extreme positions and holding out longer, often exhausting resources and damaging relationships. Both represent failed trade-offs between getting what you want and maintaining relationships.
When to use: When a negotiator is stuck in either overly accommodating or overly aggressive patterns and needs to understand the limitations of these approaches.
communicationrelationshippower_dynamics
Coaching Move Choose Principled Negotiation Over Positional Bargaining
Reject both soft and hard negotiating styles in favor of principled negotiation: decide issues on their merits rather than through haggling focused on positions. Look for mutual gains wherever possible, and where interests conflict, insist results be based on fair standards independent of either side's will. This approach is hard on merits but soft on people.
When to use: When coaching any negotiator who feels trapped between being exploited or being aggressive, or who wants a sustainable negotiation method.
communicationrelationshipcreativityethics
Framework Principled Negotiation Core Principles
Principled negotiation operates on four foundational principles: (1) Decide issues on their merits, not through positional haggling; (2) Look for mutual gains wherever possible; (3) Where interests conflict, base results on fair standards independent of either side's will; (4) Be hard on the merits while remaining soft on the people. The method employs no tricks or posturing.
When to use: When introducing a negotiator to the overall philosophy and structure that will guide their preparation and execution.
communicationcreativityethicspreparation
Quote Negotiation as Universal Daily Activity
"Negotiation is a basic means of getting what you want from others. It is back-and-forth communication designed to reach an agreement when you and the other side have some interests that are shared and others that are opposed."
When to use: When a negotiator underestimates the importance of negotiation skill or doesn't recognize a situation as negotiation.
communication
Quote Principled Negotiation Definition
"The method of principled negotiation is hard on the merits, soft on the people. It employs no tricks and no posturing. Principled negotiation shows you how to obtain what you are entitled to and still be decent."
When to use: When explaining the core value proposition and distinguishing principled negotiation from aggressive or accommodating alternatives.
communicationethicsrelationship
Example Range of Negotiation Contexts
The book opens with multiple negotiation contexts: discussing a raise with your boss, agreeing on a house price with a stranger, lawyers settling a lawsuit from a car accident, oil companies planning a joint venture, city officials meeting union leaders to avert a transit strike, and U.S.-Soviet arms control talks. This demonstrates that principled negotiation applies across vastly different scales, stakes, and party relationships.
When to use: When a negotiator thinks principled negotiation only applies to a narrow domain or doubts its relevance to their specific situation.
salarybusiness_dealspreparation
Quote Negotiation as Conflict Resolution Necessity
"More and more occasions require negotiation; conflict is a growth industry. Everyone wants to participate in decisions that affect them; fewer and fewer people will accept decisions dictated by someone else."
When to use: When motivating a negotiator to invest in learning negotiation skills given the increasing prevalence of collaborative decision-making.
communicationpower_dynamics
Coaching Move Recognize Negotiation in Daily Interactions
Understand that negotiation occurs constantly in everyday life—with spouses about dinner, with children about bedtimes, with colleagues about resources—not just in formal settings. By recognizing all interactions involving shared and opposed interests as negotiations, you become more intentional and strategic about handling them effectively.
When to use: When a negotiator needs to expand their awareness of where negotiation skills apply, especially in personal or informal contexts.
communicationpreparation
Framework Soft Negotiator Profile and Pitfalls
The soft negotiator prioritizes avoiding personal conflict and readily makes concessions to reach agreement quickly. While seeking amicable resolution, this approach often results in the negotiator being exploited and feeling bitter afterward. The soft approach represents a false choice between getting what you want and maintaining relationships.
When to use: When coaching a negotiator who tends toward over-accommodation and needs to understand the long-term costs of this approach.
relationshipemotionspower_dynamics
Framework Hard Negotiator Profile and Pitfalls
The hard negotiator views negotiation as a contest of wills, taking more extreme positions and holding out longer to win. While seeking victory, this approach often provokes equally hard responses from the other side, exhausting resources and harming the relationship. The hard approach represents a false choice between winning and maintaining relationships.
When to use: When coaching an overly aggressive negotiator who is exhausting resources or damaging important relationships through hard-bargaining tactics.
power_dynamicsrelationshipemotions
Coaching Move Reject False Dilemma Between Toughness and Fairness
Abandon the belief that you must choose between being tough and being fair, between protecting yourself and being decent. Principled negotiation proves you can be both: hard on the issues and merits while remaining soft on the people. This eliminates the felt need to either make excessive concessions or resort to aggressive tactics.
When to use: When a negotiator is anxious about being taken advantage of if they're nice, or worried that standing firm will damage relationships.
communicationrelationshipethicsemotions
Quote Principled Negotiation Universal Applicability
"Principled negotiation can be used by United States diplomats in arms control talks with the Soviet Union, by Wall Street lawyers representing Fortune 500 companies in antitrust cases, and by couples in deciding everything from where to go for vacation to how to divide their property if they get divorced. Anyone can use this method."
When to use: When addressing a negotiator's doubt about whether principled negotiation applies to their specific context or power imbalance.
business_dealssalaryrelationship
Coaching Move Use Fair Standards Instead of Positional Haggling
When interests conflict, insist that results be based on fair standards and objective criteria independent of either side's will, rather than engaging in positional haggling where each side states what it will and won't do. This shifts negotiation from a power contest to a collaborative search for legitimate justification.
When to use: When a negotiator is stuck in a back-and-forth battle of positions and needs a method to break the impasse.
leveragecommunicationcreativity
Framework Negotiation as Universal Problem-Solving Tool
Negotiation is applicable across all contexts regardless of number of issues, number of parties, presence or absence of prescribed ritual, or relative experience and negotiating style of the other side. The method works whether negotiating with experienced hard bargainers, inexperienced friendly parties, or in impromptu high-stakes situations like hostage negotiations.
When to use: When a negotiator expresses doubt about whether principled negotiation works in their specific circumstance (multi-party, complex, hostile, etc.).
preparationcommunicationdifficult_people
Coaching Move Embrace Transparency About Your Method
Unlike most negotiation strategies that become less effective if the other side learns them, principled negotiation actually becomes easier to use if the other side adopts it as well. This means you should feel comfortable being transparent about your method; the other side learning principled negotiation is not a strategic disadvantage but an advantage.
When to use: When a negotiator worries that explaining their integrative approach tips their hand or weakens their position.
communicationrelationshipethics
Quote Standard Negotiation Strategies Create Dissatisfaction
"Although negotiation takes place every day, it is not easy to do well. Standard strategies for negotiation often leave people dissatisfied, worn out, or alienated — and frequently all three."
When to use: When a negotiator feels exhausted or dissatisfied after negotiations and is open to learning a different approach.
emotionscommunication
Coaching Move Look for Mutual Gains Opportunities
In negotiation, actively search for areas where both sides can gain value together rather than assuming all value is fixed and contested. Even when some interests conflict, there are often opportunities to expand the pie and create mutual gains. This creative search is a core principle distinguishing principled negotiation from positional bargaining.
When to use: When a negotiator is locked in a zero-sum mindset or when coaching them to move from dividing value to creating value.
creativitycommunicationinformation_gathering

Ch 1. Don't Bargain Over Positions

20 items
Demonstrates through examples (including the Camp David Accords) why positional bargaining fails. When negotiators lock into positions, ego becomes entangled with substance, incentivizing stubbornness over wisdom. The more you defend a position, the more committed you become to it. Introduces principled negotiation's core mantra: be soft on the people, hard on the problem.
Coaching Move × 12 Framework × 3 Example × 2 Quote × 3
Framework Three Criteria for Judging Negotiation
Any negotiation method should be evaluated by three standards: (1) producing a wise agreement if agreement is possible, (2) being efficient, and (3) improving or at least not damaging the relationship between parties. A wise agreement meets legitimate interests of each side to the extent possible, resolves conflicting interests fairly, is durable, and takes community interests into account.
When to use: When helping a negotiator evaluate whether their current approach is working or when they're considering switching strategies.
preparationcommunicationrelationshipclosing
Coaching Move Recognize Positional Bargaining Patterns
Identify when negotiations are locked into positional bargaining: each side takes a position, argues for it, and makes concessions to reach compromise. This pattern is visible in the haggling example where customer and shopkeeper endlessly trade counteroffers without exploring underlying needs. Awareness of this pattern is the first step to changing it.
When to use: When a user describes back-and-forth counteroffers that aren't converging or feel stuck.
communicationopeningpower_dynamics
Coaching Move Identify Ego Entanglement with Position
Watch for the moment when a negotiator's ego becomes identified with their position. The more you clarify and defend your position, and the more you try to convince the other side it's impossible to change, the more committed you become and the harder it is to move. This creates a new interest in 'saving face' that prevents wise solutions.
When to use: When a user seems reluctant to budge from an opening position or is defending past statements rather than focusing on outcomes.
emotionspower_dynamicscommunication
Example Nuclear Testing Inspection Stalemate
During Kennedy-era nuclear test ban talks, the U.S. and Soviet Union deadlocked over on-site inspections: Soviets agreed to 3 per year, U.S. insisted on 10 minimum. Talks broke down despite neither side understanding what 'an inspection' actually meant (1 person for 1 day vs. 100 people for a month). Both sides focused on winning the positional battle rather than jointly designing an inspection procedure that would satisfy U.S. verification concerns and minimize intrusion for both nations.
When to use: When illustrating how positional bargaining prevents exploration of underlying interests and creative problem-solving.
information_gatheringcreativitypower_dynamics
Quote Quote: Agreement Worse Than Alternatives
"The result is frequently an agreement less satisfactory to each side than it could have been." This captures the core problem with positional bargaining: it may produce an agreement, but only by mechanical compromise rather than by carefully crafting solutions to meet legitimate interests.
When to use: When a user has reached agreement but seems unsatisfied, or when explaining why splitting the difference isn't optimal.
closingcreativity
Coaching Move Recognize Inefficiency Signals in Positional Bargaining
Positional bargaining creates perverse incentives that stall settlement: starting with extreme positions, stubborn holding, deception about true views, and minimal concessions. These tactics—extreme openings, small concessions, threats to walk out, stonewalling—all increase time, effort, and risk of no agreement. If negotiations are dragging on with small moves and increasing frustration, positional bargaining inefficiency is likely.
When to use: When a user complains negotiations are taking too long or feels stuck in incremental movement.
openingconcessionspower_dynamicsemotions
Coaching Move Spot Relationship Damage from Positional Bargaining
Recognize when positional bargaining is shifting negotiations into a contest of will where each side tries to force the other to yield through sheer power. This breeds anger and resentment as one side feels the other is ignoring legitimate concerns. Long-standing business relationships, neighborhood friendships, and family bonds can be strained or shattered by this dynamic.
When to use: When a user expresses frustration, feeling unheard, or when the relationship quality is deteriorating during negotiation.
relationshipemotionspower_dynamicsdifficult_people
Coaching Move Understand Soft vs. Hard Positional Bargaining Trap
Recognize that soft positional bargaining (being friendly, making concessions, trusting) and hard positional bargaining (making threats, demanding concessions, distrusting) are both flawed approaches. A hard bargainer will dominate a soft one because hard strategies reward intransigence. If you respond to hard positional bargaining with soft positional bargaining, you will lose. The solution is not to choose between these two but to change the game entirely.
When to use: When a user is deciding whether to be more aggressive or more accommodating, or when they've been exploited by a harder negotiator.
power_dynamicsdifficult_peoplecommunication
Example O. Henry Story: Impoverished Couple
A loving but impoverished couple each secretly sells their most prized possession to buy gifts for the other: the wife sells her hair for a watch chain while the husband sells his watch for hair combs. The analogy illustrates how soft positional bargaining focused on relationship and agreement can produce sloppy, mutually harmful outcomes when wisdom is sacrificed for amicability.
When to use: When illustrating the risks of prioritizing agreement or relationship over achieving wise outcomes.
relationshipclosingemotions
Framework Two Levels of Negotiation: Substance and Procedure
Every negotiation operates at two levels: substantive (what you're negotiating about—salary, lease terms, price) and procedural/meta-game (how you will negotiate it—soft positional bargaining, hard positional bargaining, or principled negotiation). Every move you make addresses both levels simultaneously; each move either maintains the current game or changes it. Most negotiators don't consciously notice the procedural negotiation, but it's always happening.
When to use: When helping a user understand they can change how a negotiation unfolds, not just what they're negotiating about.
preparationopeningcommunicationpower_dynamics
Framework Principled Negotiation: Four Basic Points
Principled negotiation (negotiation on the merits) is an alternative to positional bargaining designed to produce wise outcomes efficiently and amicably. It rests on four points: (1) Separate the people from the problem, (2) Focus on interests, not positions, (3) Invent options for mutual gain, (4) Insist on using objective criteria. These four elements apply across three stages: analysis (diagnosis), planning (generating solutions), and discussion (reaching agreement).
When to use: As the foundational framework for Ali's coaching across all negotiation scenarios; introduce when a user is stuck in positional bargaining.
preparationopeninginformation_gatheringcreativitycommunicationclosing
Coaching Move Separate People from Problem
Disentangle the 'people problem' (emotions, perceptions, communication, ego) from the substantive problem before or while addressing substance. People are creatures of strong emotions with different perceptions; their egos become identified with positions, making collaboration difficult. The solution: figuratively and literally, position yourselves side by side attacking the problem, not each other. Address hostile emotions, partisan perceptions, and unclear communication as separate from the substantive issue.
When to use: When emotions are high, parties feel personally attacked, or egos are blocking progress on substance.
relationshipemotionscommunicationdifficult_people
Coaching Move Focus on Underlying Interests, Not Stated Positions
A negotiating position often obscures what you really want. Compromising between positions won't satisfy the human needs that led people to adopt those positions. Shift focus to underlying interests—the needs, concerns, and values driving each position. Understanding these interests allows for solutions that actually meet the parties' real concerns rather than splitting the difference between arbitrary opening statements.
When to use: When parties are trading positions without making progress, or when you sense there's more to what they want than their stated position reflects.
information_gatheringcommunicationcreativity
Coaching Move Invent Options for Mutual Gain
Set aside designated time to brainstorm a wide range of possible solutions before deciding what to do. Pressure, high stakes, and searching for 'the one right answer' all inhibit creativity. Generate multiple options that advance shared interests and creatively reconcile differing interests. This widens vision beyond the narrow positions each side has staked out and often reveals solutions that benefit both parties more than any single position would.
When to use: When negotiations feel stuck in binary choices, or when you want to expand the pie before dividing it.
creativityinformation_gatheringopening
Coaching Move Insist on Objective Criteria
When interests are opposed, counter stubborn positional bargaining by refusing to accept 'naked will'—mere assertion of what one side will or won't do. Instead, insist that agreement reflect fair standards independent of either party's will: market value, expert opinion, custom, law, precedent, or other objective measures. This allows both parties to defer to a fair solution rather than one side giving in to the other's power.
When to use: When a negotiator is being intransigent or when parties disagree on what's fair; also useful for anchoring in ambiguous situations.
leverageanchoringclosingethics
Coaching Move Apply Principled Negotiation Across Three Stages
Use the four basic points (people, interests, options, criteria) across all three negotiation stages: (1) Analysis stage: gather information, diagnose people problems, identify your interests and the other side's, note existing options and criteria. (2) Planning stage: generate ideas and decide what to do about people problems, which interests matter most, realistic objectives, additional options and criteria. (3) Discussion stage: acknowledge differences in perception and feelings, help each side understand the other's interests, jointly generate mutually advantageous options, seek agreement on objective standards.
When to use: When structuring a negotiation from beginning to end, or when a user feels lost about what to do next.
preparationopeninginformation_gatheringcommunicationclosing
Quote Quote: Change the Game
"If you do not like the choice between hard and soft positional bargaining, you can change the game." This captures the key insight: you are not trapped between being a pushover or a bully. A third way exists that can produce better outcomes for all parties.
When to use: When a user feels forced to choose between being aggressive or accommodating; use to introduce principled negotiation as an alternative.
power_dynamicsopening
Quote Quote: Principled Negotiation Benefits
"The method permits you to reach a gradual consensus on a joint decision efficiently without all the transactional costs of digging in to positions only to have to dig yourself out of them. And separating the people from the problem allows you to deal directly and empathetically with the other negotiator as a human being, thus making possible an amicable agreement." This summarizes why principled negotiation achieves the three evaluation criteria: wise outcomes, efficiency, and preserved relationships.
When to use: When motivating a user to adopt principled negotiation or when explaining its benefits versus positional bargaining.
communicationrelationshipclosing
Coaching Move Recognize When Procedural Rules Are Being Established
Become conscious of the meta-game: every move you make not only addresses substance but also establishes or reinforces procedural rules for how the negotiation will be conducted. A collaborative tone, interest-focused questions, and proposal of objective criteria all signal a shift from positional bargaining. Use this awareness deliberately—your moves can quietly establish a principled approach even if the other side hasn't explicitly agreed to it.
When to use: When a user wants to shift the tone or rules of engagement without confronting the other party directly.
communicationpower_dynamicsopening
Coaching Move Identify Drawbacks of Multiparty Positional Bargaining
When many parties are involved (150 UN nations, boards, constituencies, higher authorities), positional bargaining becomes even more problematic: it may take all parties to say yes but only one to say no; coalitions form around symbolic shared interests rather than substantive ones; painful consensus on a position becomes nearly impossible to change; absent decision-makers can veto agreements. Principled negotiation becomes more essential, not less, in complex multiparty scenarios.
When to use: When coaching on complex negotiations with multiple stakeholders or when a user is frustrated with coalition dynamics.
team_negotiationpower_dynamicscommunication

Ch 2. Separate the People from the Problem

23 items
The first pillar. Every negotiation has two levels: the substance and the relationship. Most people treat substance and relationship as the same thing — confusing the person with the problem. This chapter breaks down three dimensions: Perception (put yourself in their shoes, don't blame them for your problems), Emotion (acknowledge feelings before problem-solving), and Communication (listen actively, speak to be understood).
Coaching Move × 8 Framework × 2 Example × 7 Quote × 6
Framework Three Categories of People Problems
All people problems in negotiation fall into three categories: perception, emotion, and communication. Rather than trying to solve people problems with substantive concessions, address each category directly using appropriate psychological techniques. This framework helps negotiators diagnose and treat the root cause of interpersonal friction.
When to use: When a negotiator is struggling with relationship or emotional issues during a negotiation and needs a structured way to think about what's really going on.
relationshipemotionscommunicationdifficult_people
Coaching Move Separate Relationship from Substance
Treat the relationship and substantive problem as two independent issues to be managed on their own merits. Base the relationship on accurate perceptions, clear communication, appropriate emotions, and forward-looking thinking. Deal with people problems directly using psychological techniques rather than trying to solve them through substantive concessions. This prevents false trade-offs where giving in on substance buys no goodwill.
When to use: When a negotiator is tempted to sacrifice substantive interests to preserve relationship, or vice versa; help them see these can be managed separately.
relationshipcommunicationdifficult_people
Coaching Move Put Yourself in Their Shoes
Develop empathetic understanding of how the other side sees the situation. This requires withholding judgment, trying on their views, and understanding the emotional force with which they hold them. It's not enough to know they see things differently—you must feel what it's like to be them. This is one of the most important skills a negotiator can possess and allows you to reduce conflict areas and advance your enlightened self-interest.
When to use: During preparation and ongoing throughout negotiation; especially when you feel stuck or misunderstood by the other party.
preparationinformation_gatheringcommunicationrelationshipemotions
Example Union Foreman Misunderstanding
Jones believes foreman Campbell is punishing him by assigning him replacement duty five times in two weeks. Campbell actually believes he's complimenting Jones by giving him responsible assignments because Jones is the best and trustworthy. Neither understood the other's perception. The union leader's investigation revealed that with flu going around, many key people were absent—not favoritism. Both parties had jumped to conclusions based on incomplete information and existing perceptions.
When to use: When illustrating how misaligned perceptions create conflict even when intentions are positive; or when showing the cost of not directly discussing differing interpretations.
perceptioncommunicationdifficult_peoplerelationship
Example Insurance Commissioner Defensive Reaction
Lawyer Monteiro approached Commissioner Thompson about problems with strict-liability insurance regulations. Thompson heard this as an attack on his intelligence and judgment—he wrote those regulations personally. He became defensive, angry, and refused to listen. The positional framing made Thompson feel his competence and integrity were being challenged, triggering emotional resistance that made productive discussion impossible.
When to use: When explaining how framing matters affect emotional reactions; or when showing the cost of not separating the person from the problem in how you present concerns.
perceptionemotionscommunicationdifficult_peopleleverage
Coaching Move Don't Deduce Intentions from Your Fears
Avoid the trap of assuming the other side intends to do whatever you fear most. Suspicious interpretations often follow naturally from existing perceptions and feel 'safe' because they show how bad the other side is. However, this costs you dearly: fresh ideas toward agreement are spurned, subtle position changes are ignored, and defensive reactions are triggered. Instead, seek alternative explanations for their behavior.
When to use: When a negotiator is interpreting ambiguous actions negatively or expressing unfounded suspicions about the other party's motives.
perceptionemotionscommunicationdifficult_people
Example New York Times Shortcut Story
A man offers a woman a ride home, takes her down unfamiliar streets claiming it's a shortcut, and gets her home so fast she catches the 10 o'clock news. The surprising ending is that nothing bad happened—she jumped to the worst conclusion based on fear. This illustrates how automatic and unconscious the process of fear-based assumption-making is.
When to use: When coaching someone who is catastrophizing or assuming worst intentions; a memorable illustration of how fear shapes perception.
perceptionemotionscommunication
Coaching Move Don't Blame Them for Your Problem
Even if blaming is justified, it is usually counterproductive. Under attack, the other side becomes defensive, stops listening, and strikes back. Blame entangles the person with the problem. Instead, describe the problem symptoms separately from the person: address the broken generator, not the unreliable company. Ask for their advice on solutions rather than assigning fault.
When to use: When a negotiator is focused on holding the other side responsible for problems and expressing this blame; redirect to problem-focused language.
communicationemotionsdifficult_peoplerelationship
Coaching Move Discuss Each Other's Perceptions Explicitly
Make differing perceptions explicit and discuss them frankly and honestly without blame. This helps each side understand why the other takes their position seriously. Also, invest time in addressing concerns the other side has that don't seem to block agreement—communicating things they want to hear is one of the best investments a negotiator can make. Don't dismiss issues as 'unimportant' just because they're not blocking a deal.
When to use: When perceptions differ significantly or when the other party raises concerns that seem tangential; use this to build credibility and attractiveness of your offer.
communicationperceptionrelationshipinformation_gathering
Example Law of the Sea Technology Transfer
Developing nations wanted technology transfer from industrialized countries for deep-seabed mining. Industrialized nations saw this as easily satisfied and therefore unimportant. By dismissing it as unimportant and dealing with it later, they gave up a low-cost opportunity to give developing countries a credible achievement and real incentive to reach agreement. By instead devoting substantial time to working out technology transfer arrangements, developed nations could have made their offer far more attractive.
When to use: When illustrating the cost of dismissing the other side's concerns as unimportant; or when showing that addressing low-cost items can increase agreement likelihood.
communicationrelationshipcreativityinformation_gathering
Coaching Move Act Inconsistently with Their Negative Perceptions
Change their perceptions by sending an unexpected message. Break the pattern they expect from you. This is perhaps the best way to change perceptions. Demonstrate through your actions that you are not what they fear. A single dramatic action inconsistent with negative expectations can shift fundamental attitudes.
When to use: When the other party holds entrenched negative views of you or your side; use a significant symbolic gesture or action that contradicts those views.
perceptionrelationshipcommunicationleverage
Example Sadat's Visit to Jerusalem
Israelis saw Egyptian President Sadat as an enemy who had launched a surprise attack four years earlier. To change this perception, Sadat flew to Jerusalem—the capital of his enemies, a disputed capital not even recognized by the United States. By acting as a partner rather than an enemy, Sadat sent a message dramatically inconsistent with Israeli expectations. This made possible the later Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty.
When to use: When illustrating the power of symbolic action to shift perceptions; or when showing how breaking expected patterns can open doors to agreement.
perceptionrelationshipleveragecommunication
Coaching Move Give Them Stake in Outcome Through Participation
Involve the other side in the process of reaching conclusions, not just the final product. If they're not involved in the process, they won't approve the product. Participate early—ask for their advice and input. Give credit generously for ideas. Even if terms seem favorable, the other side may reject them from suspicion born of exclusion from drafting. Each criticism, concession, and change becomes a personal mark the negotiator leaves, building ownership. In a sense, the process is the product.
When to use: When preparing to present proposals or when facing rejection of reasonable terms; ensure participation from the beginning, not after all decisions are made.
relationshipcommunicationpreparationopening
Example South African Pass Laws White Committee
White moderates trying to abolish discriminatory pass laws met in an all-white parliamentary committee to discuss proposals. However meritorious the proposals, they would fail because no blacks were included in the process. The message would be 'we superior whites will solve your problems'—perpetuating the very problem being addressed. Exclusion from process taints even good substantive outcomes.
When to use: When illustrating the cost of process exclusion; or when showing that procedural fairness is as important as substantive outcomes in gaining acceptance.
relationshipcommunicationprocessdifficult_people
Coaching Move Face-Saving: Reconcile Agreement with Their Principles
Help the other side accept terms by phrasing them in ways consistent with their principles, values, and past words and deeds. Face-saving is not pretense but a real need to reconcile one's negotiating position with one's self-image and principles. People often hold out not because terms are inherently unacceptable but because they want to avoid appearing to back down. If substance can be reframed so it seems fair and principled, they'll accept it. Make proposals consistent with how they see themselves.
When to use: When the other party is resisting acceptable terms; or when they seem to be holding out for ego or consistency reasons rather than substantive ones.
perceptioncommunicationemotionsrelationship
Example Mayor Announces Same Terms as Own Decision
A major city negotiated terms with its Hispanic community on municipal jobs. The mayor rejected them—until the agreement was withdrawn and the mayor was allowed to announce the same terms as his own decision, framed as fulfilling his campaign promise. Substance remained identical, but by allowing him to frame it as his own initiative consistent with his commitments, he accepted it. Face-saving was the only variable that changed.
When to use: When illustrating how reframing identical substance for face-saving purposes can move a stuck negotiation; or when showing the cost of not allowing the other party to appear to win.
perceptionemotionscommunicationrelationship
Quote People Are Not the Problem, Their Thinking Is
"Understanding the other side's thinking is not simply a useful activity that will help you solve your problem. Their thinking is the problem." Conflict exists in people's heads, not in objective reality. Differences are defined by differences in thinking, not by facts. Even established facts may do nothing to solve the problem if perceptions differ.
When to use: When a negotiator is focused on facts, evidence, or objective reality while the other side remains unmoved; remind them that perception is the real problem.
perceptioncommunicationinformation_gathering
Quote Negotiators Are People First
"A basic fact about negotiation, easy to forget in corporate and international transactions, is that you are dealing not with abstract representatives of the 'other side,' but with human beings. They have emotions, deeply held values, and different backgrounds and viewpoints; and they are unpredictable." Remembering this humanity is essential to navigating people problems effectively.
When to use: When a negotiator is approaching negotiation too mechanically or abstractly, forgetting the human element; remind them of the fundamental human reality.
relationshipemotionscommunicationdifficult_people
Quote Two Interests Every Negotiator Has
"Every negotiator wants to reach an agreement that satisfies his substantive interests. That is why one negotiates. Beyond that, a negotiator also has an interest in his relationship with the other side." Most negotiations occur in ongoing relationships where future dealings matter more than any single negotiation. Managing both interests is essential.
When to use: When a negotiator is sacrificing relationship for short-term substantive gains, or vice versa; remind them both interests deserve attention.
relationshipleverage
Quote Don't Solve People Problems with Substance
"To deal with psychological problems, use psychological techniques." Don't try to solve perception, emotion, or communication problems by making substantive concessions. This wastes leverage and produces no goodwill. Address the root cause directly instead.
When to use: When a negotiator is trading away substantive position to fix a people problem; remind them to use the right tool for the right problem.
communicationrelationshipemotions
Quote The Relationship-Substance Entanglement
"The relationship tends to become entangled with the problem." Parties treat people and problem as one unit. Substantive discussions get interpreted as personal attacks. Positional bargaining especially aggravates this by creating the impression that firm positions demonstrate you don't care about the relationship. Consciously separate these two elements.
When to use: When explaining why emotions are running high in what should be a straightforward discussion; help them see how substance and relationship became entangled.
relationshipemotionscommunicationperception
Quote In a Sense, the Process Is the Product
"Apart from the substantive merits, the feeling of participation in the process is perhaps the single most important factor in determining whether a negotiator accepts a proposal. In a sense, the process is the product." How you reach an agreement matters as much as what the agreement contains.
When to use: When a negotiator is focused only on substantive outcomes and wondering why reasonable proposals are being rejected; refocus on process quality.
relationshipcommunicationprocess
Framework Tenant-Landlord Perception Matrix
A detailed comparison showing how the same facts (rent level, apartment condition, payment timeliness, tenant age, neighborhood status) are perceived completely differently by each party. Tenant sees high rent, wear and tear is normal, landlord is cold; Landlord sees overdue increases needed, heavy wear, reasonable rates elsewhere, neighborhood improvement requires higher rents. Each interprets identical behaviors (asking for rent, assigning work) through opposite lenses (lack of respect vs. consideration). This illustrates how systematically and unconsciously people's perceptions diverge.
When to use: When coaching someone to understand how the same situation looks completely different to the other party; helps build empathy for why they're not seeing what seems obvious.

Ch 3. Focus on Interests, Not Positions

25 items
The second pillar. Positions are what people say they want; interests are why they want it. Behind opposed positions lie shared and compatible interests, not just conflicting ones. The most powerful interests are basic human needs: security, economic well-being, a sense of belonging, recognition, and control over one's life. Techniques: ask 'Why?' and 'Why not?' to uncover what's really driving the other side.
Coaching Move × 10 Framework × 3 Example × 7 Quote × 5
Framework Positions vs. Interests Model
Distinguish between a negotiator's stated position (what they say they want) and their underlying interests (the needs, desires, concerns, and fears that motivate that position). Positions are concrete and explicit; interests are often unexpressed, intangible, and multiple. Solving negotiations requires identifying and reconciling interests, not compromising on positions.
When to use: When a negotiator feels stuck or believes the other party is being inflexible, help them shift focus from positions to underlying motivations.
preparationinformation_gatheringcommunication
Coaching Move Ask 'Why?' to Uncover Interests
When the other party takes a position, ask them directly why they hold it. Frame the question to seek understanding of their needs, hopes, fears, or desires—not justification of their stance. Example: 'What's your basic concern, Mr. Jones, in wanting the lease to run for no more than three years?' This reveals the interests driving their position.
When to use: During information-gathering phases when you need to understand what motivates the other party's stated demands.
information_gatheringcommunication
Coaching Move Ask 'Why Not?' to Map Their Decision
Identify the basic decision you are asking the other side to make, then ask yourself why they haven't made it yet. What interests stand in the way? This reverses perspective and helps you understand their current thinking. Use a decision balance sheet (IF YES / IF NO columns) to map the consequences they perceive of accepting or rejecting your proposal.
When to use: When negotiations stall or the other party refuses to move; use this to diagnose hidden obstacles rooted in their interests.
information_gatheringleveragecommunication
Framework Decision Balance Sheet Method
Create a two-column chart showing consequences of agreeing vs. refusing to make a requested decision from the other party's perspective. Include: impact on their personal interests, impact on group interests, short/long-term consequences, economic/political/legal/psychological effects, precedent impact, consistency with principles, and whether they can revisit later. This reveals why they cling to their current position.
When to use: During preparation or diagnosis when trying to understand why the other party resists your proposals.
preparationinformation_gathering
Coaching Move Recognize Multiple Interests Per Party
Understand that each negotiator typically has many interests simultaneously: affecting the outcome, reaching agreement quickly, maintaining relationship, addressing personal needs and group needs. Additionally, assume that different individuals and factions on the other side may have differing interests. Avoid the error of treating 'the other side' as monolithic.
When to use: During preparation or when diagnosing complex negotiations involving multiple decision-makers or stakeholders on either side.
preparationteam_negotiationdifficult_people
Framework Basic Human Needs Priority Framework
Recognize that the most powerful interests are grounded in universal human needs: security, economic well-being, a sense of belonging, recognition, and control over one's life. These bedrock concerns motivate all people across cultures and contexts. Addressing these needs increases likelihood of agreement and compliance. Even monetary negotiations often disguise deeper needs (e.g., alimony as proxy for security and recognition, not just cash).
When to use: When analyzing the other party's interests, especially when simple economic explanations seem insufficient or when agreements keep falling apart.
preparationinformation_gatheringemotionsrelationship
Coaching Move Write Down All Interests as a List
Create a written inventory of interests as they emerge during preparation and discovery. This aids memory, enables refinement as you learn new information, allows rank-ordering by importance, and stimulates creative idea-generation for meeting multiple interests simultaneously.
When to use: During preparation phase to organize your thinking and ensure you don't lose sight of any important motivations.
preparation
Coaching Move Identify Shared and Compatible Interests
Move beyond the assumption that opposed positions mean opposed interests. Carefully examine what you and the other party have in common or what interests, while different, can be mutually satisfied. Example: tenant and landlord both want stability, maintenance, and good relationship—these shared interests can form the foundation of agreement even where rent amounts differ.
When to use: During preparation or early negotiation phases to reframe the negotiation as collaborative rather than zero-sum.
creativitypreparationrelationship
Example Library Window Story
Two men argue over an open vs. closed window. A librarian asks why each wants their position: one needs fresh air, the other wants to avoid drafts. Rather than compromise (quarter-open), she opens a different window, satisfying both interests. This illustrates that focusing on interests reveals creative solutions impossible if locked into positions.
When to use: Use this vivid story when coaching someone stuck in positional bargaining to help them shift to interest-based thinking.
creativitycommunication
Example Camp David Sinai Demilitarization Agreement
Israel's position: keep part of Sinai for security. Egypt's position: return all Sinai for sovereignty. Both positions seemed incompatible. Underlying interests: Israel needed security (no Egyptian tanks on border); Egypt needed sovereignty (flag and control of territory). Solution: return all Sinai to Egyptian control but demilitarize it—Egyptian flag everywhere, no tanks near Israel. This satisfied both interests while both positions seemed irreconcilable.
When to use: Cite this high-stakes geopolitical example when coaching negotiators to show how interest-based thinking unlocks seemingly impossible conflicts and creates wins for both parties.
creativitypreparation
Example Tenant-Landlord Shared Interests Case
A tenant and landlord initially appear to have opposed interests on rent. Deeper analysis reveals: both want stability (tenant wants permanent address, landlord wants stable tenant); both want maintenance (tenant will live there, landlord wants property value/building reputation); both want good relationship (landlord wants timely payment, tenant wants responsive repairs). Shared interests form basis for long lease, shared improvement costs, mutual accommodation. Only the specific rent amount remains truly contested.
When to use: Use this domestic real-world example to teach the principle that most negotiations contain far more shared/compatible interests than opposed ones.
creativitypreparationrelationship
Example Iran Hostage Crisis Decision Balance Sheet
During 1980 hostage negotiations, the choice facing Iranian student leaders was: release hostages (yes) or keep holding them (no). If yes: seem weak, betray revolution, face criticism, risk no benefit. If no: uphold revolution, gain world attention for grievances, maintain leverage, keep U.S. uncertain. Understanding this balance sheet explains why immediate release seemed irrational to them—the hostages provided ongoing value as leverage and domestic political support. This demonstrates why simple demands fail without addressing the other party's actual decision calculus.
When to use: Use when coaching negotiators facing apparent irrationality from the other party; helps reframe their behavior as internally logical when you understand their full decision context.
information_gatheringleveragedifficult_people
Example U.S.-Mexico Natural Gas Price Dispute
The U.S. focused only on lowering Mexico's gas price (economic interest). The U.S. Secretary of Energy rejected a negotiated price increase, assuming Mexico would then lower demands. Instead, Mexico burned off the gas rather than accept what felt like bullying disrespect. The missed interest: Mexico's need for respectful treatment and sense of equality. Ignoring basic human needs (recognition, respect) made the economic negotiation politically impossible.
When to use: Cite when a negotiator is focusing solely on monetary terms while missing relationship, respect, or recognition interests that may actually block agreement.
emotionsrelationshipleverage
Example Baseball Salary Negotiation - Hidden Constituency
A general manager insisted $500,000 was too much for a player despite market evidence others paid that. The manager felt his position was unjustifiable but had strict orders from owners hiding financial difficulties. The negotiator's interests weren't his own; they belonged to his constituency. Understanding that every negotiator answers to someone (employer, client, family, faction) is key to understanding why they take seemingly irrational positions.
When to use: Use when analyzing why the other party won't move; helps identify hidden constraints and decision-makers behind the negotiator at the table.
team_negotiationinformation_gatheringdifficult_people
Example Construction Project Complaint - Truck Safety
Citizens complained about construction trucks on their street. Rather than state position ('build a fence'), the group explained interests: ensuring children's safety and getting sleep. They provided specific evidence (three near-misses, 40 mph truck on residential street). By making interests vivid and legitimate, they created space for the construction company to address the actual problem, not just defend against demands.
When to use: Cite as a model for how to communicate interests vividly and specifically when negotiating with organizations or difficult counterparties.
communicationleverage
Coaching Move Make Interests Come Alive with Specificity
When explaining your interests, use concrete details and specific examples rather than abstract claims. Replace 'trucks are dangerous' with 'Three times in the last week a child was almost hit; Tuesday at 8:30 AM, a 40 mph red gravel truck barely missed hitting seven-year-old Loretta Johnson.' Concrete details make your interests credible, legitimate, and emotionally resonant.
When to use: When preparing to communicate your interests or concerns to the other party; use this to maximize impact and prevent them dismissing your concerns as minor.
communicationleverageemotions
Coaching Move Establish Legitimacy of Your Interests
Frame your interests not as personal attacks on the other party but as legitimate problems demanding attention. Use perspective-taking to build empathy: 'Do you have children? How would you feel if trucks were hurtling 40 mph down your street?' This shows the other party that they would naturally share your concerns if in your position, making your interests seem reasonable rather than adversarial.
When to use: When presenting interests to the other party, especially in contentious situations where they may perceive your concerns as criticism.
communicationrelationshipemotions
Coaching Move Acknowledge Their Interests as Part of the Problem
Begin by demonstrating understanding of the other party's interests before asking them to understand yours. People listen better and regard those who understand them as intelligent and sympathetic. Frame their interests as legitimate concerns that are part of the overall problem to solve, especially if shared: 'It would be terrible for all of us if one of your trucks hit a child.' This builds reciprocal understanding.
When to use: Early in interest-sharing discussions; use this to create psychological safety and reciprocal willingness to listen.
communicationrelationshipemotions
Coaching Move Lead with Interests, Then Proposals
When communicating to the other party, present your interests and reasoning first, then your proposed solutions or positions last. If you lead with your position ('build a fence within 48 hours'), the other party stops listening and prepares counterarguments. If you lead with interests ('we're terrified about children's safety and can't sleep'), they listen carefully to understand where you're headed—and when you then propose solutions, they understand the 'why' behind them.
When to use: When presenting your case to the other party, especially in opening statements or when trying to gain understanding and buy-in.
communicationopening
Coaching Move Look Forward to Interests, Not Backward to Causes
Focus negotiations on future purposes (where you want to go) rather than past causes (why past actions occurred). Instead of arguing about last quarter's costs, last week's broken commitments, or yesterday's performance, ask 'Who should do what tomorrow?' This orients parties toward shared problem-solving rather than blame-scoring. You satisfy your interests better by pursuing forward-looking solutions than by relitigating history.
When to use: When negotiations become mired in blame, grievances, or rehashing past conflicts; use to refocus energy on future-oriented problem-solving.
communicationrelationshipemotions
Quote Interests vs. Positions Core Insight
'For a wise solution reconcile interests, not positions.' This captures the central principle: agreements built on compromised positions are fragile, but solutions reconciling underlying interests create value and durability.
When to use: Use this concise statement as the foundational principle when shifting a negotiator from positional to interest-based thinking.
communicationpreparation
Quote Why Your Interests Motivate Position-Taking
'Your position is something you have decided upon. Your interests are what caused you to so decide.' This explains the causal mechanism: interests are the silent movers behind positions, making them primary objects of understanding.
When to use: Use when helping someone understand why the other party holds their position; reframes their seemingly arbitrary demands as driven by comprehensible motivations.
communicationinformation_gathering
Quote Multiple Interests Behind Opposed Positions
'Behind opposed positions lie shared and compatible interests, as well as conflicting ones.' This directly counters the assumption that opposed positions mean opposed interests, opening space for integrative solutions.
When to use: When a negotiator assumes the negotiation is purely adversarial and both sides' interests are fundamentally opposed; use to reframe possibility space.
creativitypreparation
Quote Agreement Through Differing Interests
'Agreement is often made possible precisely because interests differ. You and a shoe-seller may both like money and shoes. Relatively, his interest in the thirty dollars exceeds his interest in the shoes. For you, the situation is reversed: you like the shoes better than the thirty dollars. Hence the deal.' This captures how trades become possible through complementary rather than identical interests.
When to use: When explaining to negotiators why apparent conflicts can be the basis for mutually beneficial trades; teaches that difference in interest ordering enables value creation.
creativitypreparation
Quote People Listen When Understood
'People listen better if they feel that you have understood them. They tend to think that those who understand them are intelligent and sympathetic people whose own opinions may be worth listening to.' This explains the reciprocal psychology of acknowledgment—understanding generates listening.
When to use: When coaching someone on building rapport and ensuring the other party is receptive to understanding their interests in turn.

Ch 5. Insist on Using Objective Criteria

22 items
The fourth pillar. Rather than resolving differences through willpower or threats, base agreements on fair standards (market value, precedent, scientific judgment, professional norms, costs, legal rulings) and fair procedures (taking turns, drawing lots, third-party arbitration). This chapter teaches how to frame any demand as a question of principle rather than pressure.
Coaching Move × 10 Framework × 3 Example × 3 Quote × 6
Framework Objective Criteria vs. Positional Bargaining
Positional bargaining resolves conflicts by each side stating what they will or won't accept, leading to contests of will where someone must back down. Objective criteria-based negotiation resolves conflicts by reference to independent standards (market value, precedent, scientific judgment, fairness standards, etc.) that neither side controls. The latter produces wise, amicable, and efficient agreements while protecting relationships.
When to use: When a user is stuck in positional bargaining or facing will-based resistance, use this framework to show them why shifting to objective criteria is strategically superior.
preparationcommunicationpower_dynamicsethics
Coaching Move Frame Issue as Joint Search
Reframe the negotiation from opposing positions to a shared goal of finding fairness. Say something like: 'You want X and I want Y. Let's figure out what's fair. What objective standards might be relevant?' This transforms the dynamic from adversarial to collaborative problem-solving around criteria, not positions.
When to use: At the opening or when stuck in positional deadlock, to reset the negotiation frame toward principled discussion.
openingcommunicationrelationshipcreativity
Coaching Move Ask 'What's Your Theory?'
When the other side states a position (e.g., 'The price is $55,000'), immediately ask for the reasoning behind it: 'How did you arrive at that figure?' This shifts focus from the position itself to the justification, inviting them to think in terms of standards rather than demands.
When to use: When the other side opens with a positional statement; use it to probe for underlying logic and redirect toward criteria-based discussion.
openinginformation_gatheringcommunication
Coaching Move Agree on Principles First
Before discussing specific terms or offers, agree on which standard or criteria will apply to the decision. Once they accept a standard, they become bound by it logically—their own criterion becomes a lever you can use to persuade them, and departing from it looks like weakness, not negotiating.
When to use: Early in substantive negotiation, to establish the playing field before numbers are on the table.
preparationopeningcommunicationleverage
Coaching Move Use Their Criterion Against Them
If the other side proposes a standard (e.g., 'comparable sales'), affirm it and then apply it to your case: 'You say Mr. Jones sold next door for $60,000 and comparable houses are the standard. Let's look at three other comparable sales.' Presenting your case in their terms makes it harder to resist, and accepting it becomes an act of consistency, not weakness.
When to use: Once they've proposed a standard; use it to advance your position within the framework they've endorsed.
leveragecommunicationconcessions
Coaching Move Reason and Remain Open to Reason
Come to the table genuinely prepared to consider alternative standards, not just defend your own. Listen to their reasoning, be willing to shift standards if theirs are legitimate, and look for objective bases to choose between competing standards (e.g., past practice, wider usage). This openness is what makes principled negotiation persuasive and distinct from positional use of standards.
When to use: Throughout negotiation when discussing which criteria apply; model genuine openness to persuasion as a way to earn reciprocal openness.
communicationrelationshipemotions
Coaching Move Never Yield to Pressure, Only to Principle
When faced with threats, bribes, appeals to trust, or refusals to budge, respond by isolating the pressure from the merits: 'A job for my brother-in-law has nothing to do with foundation depth' or 'Trust is separate; let's settle this on the merits.' Refuse to yield except in response to sound reasons rooted in objective criteria.
When to use: When the other side applies pressure (threats, emotional appeals, ultimatums); use this to maintain principled resistance without appearing stubborn.
difficult_peopleleveragepower_dynamicsemotions
Coaching Move Offer Third-Party Standard Judgment
If you cannot agree on which standard applies after thorough discussion, propose submitting the question (not the substantive dispute) to a fair third party for advice: 'Let's ask someone we both trust which standard is fairest here.' This avoids arbitration of the outcome while gaining agreement on process.
When to use: When you and the other side have competing legitimate standards that produce different results and you're reaching impasse on which to use.
closingleveragecommunication
Framework Categories of Objective Criteria
Standards for resolving disputes include: market value, precedent, scientific judgment, professional standards, efficiency, costs, what a court would decide, moral standards, equal treatment, tradition, reciprocity, and others. Different negotiations may call for different criteria. At minimum, criteria should be independent of both sides' will; ideally, they should be legitimate, practical, and applicable to both parties (reciprocal application test).
When to use: During preparation; help the user brainstorm which standards are available and legitimate for their specific negotiation.
preparationcreativity
Framework Fair Procedures Framework
When substantive standards are hard to agree on, use fair procedures: (1) 'One cuts, the other chooses'—divide the problem or decision-making authority so the proposer bears the risk of unfairness; (2) Taking turns; (3) Drawing lots or coin flips (equal opportunity, unequal outcome); (4) Expert advice or mediation; (5) Binding arbitration; (6) Last-best-offer arbitration (forces realism). These procedures remove will-based bargaining and often harness the other side's incentives for fairness.
When to use: When direct agreement on substantive criteria is difficult; use procedural fairness to structure a solution that feels objective to both sides.
preparationcreativityclosing
Example Law of the Sea Deep Seabed Mining Fee
India proposed a $60M initial fee for mining permits; the US opposed any fee. Both sides dug in. Then MIT developed an economic model for mining feasibility. When applied objectively, the model showed India's fee would bankrupt mining operations (no revenue for 5 years), and it convinced India to reconsider. The model also educated US reps that some fee was economically viable. Both sides changed positions based on principle, not pressure. No one backed down or looked weak; they reached a mutually satisfactory agreement that would attract mining AND generate government revenue.
When to use: When a user is in a positional stalemate; show how introducing an objective model/standard can unlock movement from both sides and create mutual gain without anyone appearing weak.
leveragecreativityclosingbusiness_deals
Example House Foundation Depth Dispute
A contractor proposes 2-foot foundations; the owner believes 5 feet is standard. Rather than horse-trade ('You gave on girders, now give on foundations'), the owner insists on objective standards: government specifications for soil conditions, depths in neighboring buildings, earthquake risk data. This illustrates principled negotiation in action—refusing will-based compromise in favor of standards.
When to use: When a user is tempted to compromise on substantive safety/merit issues; show why insisting on objective standards is the right move.
preparationcommunicationethics
Example Insurance Claim Negotiation (Tom and Adjuster)
Tom's car was destroyed; insurance adjuster offers $3,300 citing 'company policy.' Tom asks how the figure was derived (no answer). Tom then proposes fair replacement cost standard: he found a comparable car for $3,850 + tax = $4,000. Adjuster refuses, says policy limits him to $3,500. Tom says: 'Unless you can state objectively why that amount is fair, I'll do better in court. Let's study and talk Wednesday.' This shifts from positional ($3,500 take-it-or-leave-it) to criteria-based (what's a fair replacement standard?). The dialogue shows Tom using objective criteria to resist pressure and invite principled discussion.
When to use: When a user faces a 'company policy' or arbitrary ceiling; show how to push back with objective standards and offer to reconvene on merits, not will.
difficult_peopleleveragecommunication
Quote Principled Negotiation Produces Wise Agreements
'Principled negotiation produces wise agreements amicably and efficiently.' The more you bring standards of fairness, efficiency, or scientific merit to bear, the more likely you produce a final package that is wise and fair.
When to use: When a user is unsure whether it's worth the effort to ground negotiation in objective criteria; cite this to motivate the approach.
ethicscommunication
Quote Constant Battle for Dominance Threatens Relationships
'A constant battle for dominance threatens a relationship; principled negotiation protects it.' It is far easier to deal with people when both of you discuss objective standards instead of trying to force each other to back down.
When to use: When a user is worried that insisting on criteria will damage a relationship; show that it actually protects relationships vs. will-based bargaining.
relationshipcommunication
Quote Focus on Merits, Not Mettle of Parties
'Commit yourself to reaching a solution based on principle, not pressure. Concentrate on the merits of the problem, not the mettle of the parties. Be open to reason, but closed to threats.'
When to use: When a user is being swayed by personal charm, intimidation, or relationship dynamics; remind them to focus on substance and standards, not personalities.
communicationpower_dynamicsemotions
Quote Never Yield Except on the Basis of Sound Reasons
'A refusal to yield except in response to sound reasons is an easier position to defend — publicly and privately — than is a refusal to yield combined with a refusal to advance sound reasons.' Principle serves as your 'hardhearted partner' that will not let you yield to pressure; it is a form of 'right makes might.'
When to use: When a user feels they should make a concession to close a deal; show why holding firm on principle is stronger and more defensible than arbitrary giving.
leveragepower_dynamicsclosing
Quote Principled Negotiation as Dominant Strategy
'One who insists that negotiation be based on the merits can bring others around to playing that game, since that becomes the only way to advance their substantive interests.' Principled negotiation is a dominant strategy over positional bargaining.
When to use: When a user is uncertain whether taking a principled stance will work; show that insisting on merits-based discussion is strategically superior and will shift the other side's behavior.
power_dynamicsleveragecommunication
Quote Reciprocal Application Test for Fair Standards
'Objective criteria should apply, at least in theory, to both sides. You can thus use the test of reciprocal application to tell you whether a proposed criterion is fair and independent of either party's will.' If the seller uses a standard form contract, ask if they use the same form when they buy.
When to use: When evaluating whether a criterion the other side proposes is truly fair; use the reciprocal test to expose double standards.
ethicscommunicationleverage
Coaching Move Develop Objective Criteria in Advance
Before negotiating, prepare a list of multiple objective standards that could apply to your dispute (market value, precedent, cost, professional standards, etc.). Think through how each would apply to your specific case. This preparation allows you to propose criteria confidently and recognizes that multiple legitimate standards may exist—some of which may favor the other side.
When to use: During preparation phase; encourage thorough advance work on available standards so you're not caught flat-footed in the negotiation.
preparation
Coaching Move Assess Your BATNA Against Unjustified Positions
If the other side will not budge and offers no principled basis for their position, treat it like a fixed-price store: take it or leave it. Before walking away, check if you've missed any objective standard that makes their offer fair. If not, weigh whether accepting their arbitrary position gains more than your BATNA, and also weigh reputational cost of capitulating vs. benefit of deal.
When to use: When negotiation reaches impasse and you're considering whether to accept an apparently unjustified position; use this framework to decide.
alternativesclosingleverage
Coaching Move Distinguish Principled Negotiation from Positional Use of Standards
Do not use objective criteria merely as arguments in support of a predetermined position (e.g., citing other cities' police salaries to defend your demand). Instead, genuinely search for the right standard, be open to the other side's reasoning, and use standards to move toward agreement, not to entrench. Announcing 'it's a matter of principle' and refusing to consider the other side's case is not principled negotiation—it's positional bargaining with ideology.
When to use: If a user is starting to weaponize standards or is being rigid about their chosen criterion; clarify the distinction between genuine principled negotiation and positional use of criteria.
communicationethicsrelationship
