Ch 6. Develop Your BATNA (What If They Are More Powerful?)

23 items
Introduces BATNA — Best Alternative To a Negotiated Agreement — perhaps the single most important concept in all of negotiation theory. Your BATNA is your walkaway power: the better your alternatives, the less you need this deal. The chapter teaches how to identify, develop, and improve your BATNA before entering any negotiation, and how to assess the other side's BATNA.
Coaching Move × 13 Framework × 1 Example × 4 Quote × 5
Coaching Move Reject the Bottom Line Approach
Instead of setting a rigid predetermined bottom line (e.g., 'I won't sell for less than $160,000'), recognize that bottom lines shut your ears to new information, inhibit creative problem-solving, and are often set arbitrarily too high or too low. Bottom lines prevent you from discovering tailor-made solutions that better serve your interests by combining multiple variables (price, timing, contingencies, options).
When to use: When a negotiator mentions using a bottom line or seems locked into a rigid position, explain why this approach backfires.
preparationleveragecreativityclosing
Framework BATNA Framework: Best Alternative to Negotiated Agreement
Replace the bottom line concept with BATNA—the standard against which any proposed agreement should be measured. BATNA is the concrete alternative you will pursue if negotiation fails. It protects you from accepting unfavorable terms AND from rejecting favorable terms. BATNA must be realistic, not aggregated, and thoroughly developed before negotiating.
When to use: Introduce this framework early in preparation as the foundation for all negotiation strategy and decision-making.
preparationalternativesleverageclosing
Coaching Move Develop Your BATNA Through Three Operations
First, invent a comprehensive list of actions you could take if no agreement is reached (e.g., seek alternative job offers, call a strike, work without a contract). Second, improve the most promising ideas by converting them into practical, actionable alternatives (e.g., actually pursue a job offer in another city). Third, select tentatively the single best option among your realistic alternatives. This three-step process turns vague possibilities into concrete negotiating power.
When to use: During preparation phase, coach negotiators through a systematic BATNA development process rather than allowing them to skip this step.
preparationalternativesleverage
Coaching Move Identify Trip Wire Before Negotiating
In addition to your BATNA, establish a trip wire: a threshold agreement that is better than your BATNA but far from ideal. If negotiations approach this trigger point, pause and reexamine. This provides early warning, gives agents clear authority limits, and preserves negotiating room (margin in reserve) for potential mediators. Example: 'Don't accept less than $158,000 without calling me first.'
When to use: When preparing to negotiate and establishing guardrails, especially for team negotiations or when using agents/representatives.
preparationleverageteam_negotiation
Coaching Move Measure Agreements Against BATNA, Not Arbitrary Standards
When evaluating any offer or proposal, ask: 'Is this better than my BATNA?' not 'Is this what I think I should get?' This standard is objective, interest-based, and prevents both accepting bad deals and rejecting good ones. Your BATNA is the only legitimate measure of whether an agreement serves your interests.
When to use: During negotiations when evaluating proposals, or when coaching someone who is uncertain whether to accept an offer.
closingdecision-makingalternatives
Coaching Move Avoid Psychological Aggregation of Alternatives
Don't mentally combine all your possible alternatives ('I could go to California, or the South, or back to school, or work on a farm') and treat that sum as your BATNA. If negotiations fail, you'll only be able to pursue one alternative, not all of them. Be realistic about which single option you'll actually choose.
When to use: When a negotiator seems unrealistically optimistic about their alternatives or is using vague aggregated reasoning.
preparationalternativesleverage
Coaching Move Don't Negotiate Without Understanding Your BATNA
If you haven't carefully thought through what you'll do if no agreement is reached, you're 'negotiating with your eyes closed.' You'll either be too optimistic about alternatives you don't really have, or too pessimistic about the consequences of failure. You must have at least a tentative BATNA before entering substantive negotiations.
When to use: When someone wants to start negotiating without adequate preparation, emphasize this risk.
preparationalternatives
Coaching Move Convert Resources into BATNA Power, Not Direct Power
Wealth, political connections, and physical strength don't automatically create negotiating power. A wealthy tourist buying a brass pot has no advantage unless he researches alternative sources. Power comes from having an attractive BATNA. Apply your resources (knowledge, time, money, people, connections, wits) to develop the best independent solution, not to dominate the other side.
When to use: When a negotiator assumes their resources or status guarantee them power, reframe power in terms of BATNA.
leveragepower_dynamicsalternatives
Coaching Move Build Confidence by Knowing You Can Walk Away
Having a solid BATNA gives you the psychological confidence and willingness to break off negotiations if necessary. The easier and happier you can walk away, the more forcefully you can present your interests and the stronger your actual negotiating position. This confidence is often visible and strengthens your hand.
When to use: When coaching someone who feels anxious or desperate during negotiations.
leveragepower_dynamicsalternativesemotions
Coaching Move Evaluate Disclosing Your BATNA Strategically
If your BATNA is extremely attractive (e.g., another customer in the next room), disclose it. If the other side underestimates your BATNA, revealing it will strengthen your position. However, if they overestimate your BATNA, keep quiet. Disclosure is a strategic decision based on their perception, not a rule.
When to use: When a negotiator is deciding what information to reveal, discuss strategic disclosure of BATNA.
communicationleveragepower_dynamicsinformation_gathering
Coaching Move Research and Estimate the Other Side's BATNA
Invest effort in learning what alternatives are available to the other side if no agreement is reached. They may be unrealistically optimistic (aggregating alternatives) or unaware of their real options. Understanding their BATNA helps you realistically estimate what outcomes are achievable and whether they're truly motivated to negotiate.
When to use: During preparation and information-gathering phases, coach negotiators to research the other side's alternatives.
preparationinformation_gatheringleveragepower_dynamics
Coaching Move Recognize When Non-Agreement Is the Best Outcome
If both sides have attractive BATNAs, the best outcome may be no agreement at all. A successful negotiation is sometimes one where both parties amicably discover their interests are better served by pursuing alternatives. Don't force agreement when walking away is optimal.
When to use: When negotiations seem to be dragging on unproductively, or when the other side's BATNA is genuinely superior.
closingpower_dynamicsalternatives
Coaching Move Shift to Principle-Based Negotiation When Outgunned
If the other side has superior economic or physical power, don't turn the negotiation into a power contest. Instead, establish principle and merit as the basis for agreement. To the extent they have 'muscle' and you have 'principle,' make principle the larger part of the negotiation. A good BATNA enables you to negotiate on merits rather than capitulating to force.
When to use: When coaching a negotiator facing a more powerful opponent in terms of resources or leverage.
leveragepower_dynamicscommunication
Coaching Move Change the Other Side's BATNA If It's Too Attractive
If the other side's BATNA is so good they see no need to negotiate seriously (e.g., a power company knowing they can complete construction despite community protests), consider what you can do to make non-agreement less attractive to them. If their walk-away option is better than any negotiated solution you can offer, the negotiation won't succeed unless you change their alternatives (e.g., filing suit to revoke permits).
When to use: When the other side seems unmotivated to negotiate because their alternative is too attractive.
leveragepower_dynamicsalternatives
Example House Sale Pricing Example
A family selling a house debates setting a bottom line of $160,000 (their minimum acceptable price). But this ignores what they'll actually do if unsold: rent it, tear it down, use land as parking lot, or let someone live rent-free while they paint it. Comparing these alternatives reveals the true BATNA. Selling for $124,000 might beat holding indefinitely; selling for more than an attractive rental return might be unnecessary. No arbitrary bottom line reflects their actual interests.
When to use: When illustrating why bottom lines are arbitrary and BATNA-thinking is superior.
preparationalternativesleverage
Example Job Offer Salary Negotiation Example
Walking into a job interview with no other offers and vague leads creates weak negotiating power. Walking in with two competing job offers creates strong power. The difference isn't the candidate's underlying value—it's their BATNA. The two offers are concrete, attractive alternatives that change the salary negotiation fundamentally.
When to use: When coaching someone preparing for salary negotiation, use this relatable example to illustrate BATNA power.
leveragesalarypower_dynamics
Example Small Town vs. Factory Tax Negotiation
A small town negotiated a factory from a $300,000 annual 'goodwill' payment to $2,300,000 by developing a superior BATNA: expanding town limits to include the factory and taxing it at residential rates (~$2,500,000/year). The corporation appeared powerful (major employer, critical to local economy) but had committed to keeping the factory with no alternative. The town's concrete BATNA gave it more negotiating power than one of the world's largest corporations despite apparent resource inequality.
When to use: When illustrating how BATNA creates power independent of apparent resources or leverage.
leveragepower_dynamicsalternativesbusiness_deals
Example Brass Pot Vendor at Bombay Station
A wealthy tourist trying to buy a brass pot from a poor vendor has less negotiating power if he doesn't know alternative sources. The vendor, though poor, knows the market and can sell to someone else. The tourist's wealth doesn't strengthen his power unless he applies it to research comparable pots elsewhere. His BATNA (buying similar pot elsewhere) determines his actual power, not his wealth.
When to use: When explaining why apparent resources (wealth, status) don't equal negotiating power.
leveragepower_dynamicsalternatives
Quote BATNA as the True Standard
'That is the standard against which any proposed agreement should be measured. That is the only standard which can protect you both from accepting terms that are too unfavorable and from rejecting terms it would be in your interest to accept.' (Referring to BATNA, not arbitrary bottom lines)
When to use: When emphasizing why BATNA replaces bottom lines as the decision framework.
alternativesclosingleverage
Quote Power Depends on BATNA, Not Resources
'In fact, the relative negotiating power of two parties depends primarily upon how attractive to each is the option of not reaching agreement.' (Regarding what truly determines negotiating power)
When to use: When reframing a negotiator's understanding of power away from resources and toward BATNA.
leveragepower_dynamicsalternatives
Quote The Cost of Bottom Lines
'A bottom line — by its very nature rigid — is almost certain to be too rigid.' (Explaining the fundamental flaw in bottom line thinking)

preparationalternatives
Quote Walking Away Creates Power
'It is easier to break off negotiations if you know where you're going. The greater your willingness to break off negotiations, the more forcefully you can present your interests and the basis on which you believe an agreement should be reached.' (On BATNA's psychological benefits)

Ch 7. Negotiation Jujitsu (What If They Won't Play?)

50 items
When the other side refuses principled negotiation — attacking your position, asserting theirs, or attacking you personally — don't fight back. Use 'negotiation jujitsu': redirect their attacks into explorations of interests. Ask questions instead of making statements. Use silence after unreasonable proposals. The one-text mediator procedure: draft a single document, critique it collaboratively, iterate until both sides can live with it.

Framework BATNA - Best Alternative to Negotiated Agreement
BATNA is the standard against which any proposed agreement should be measured. It represents what you will actually do if negotiations fail, not an arbitrary bottom line. Your BATNA protects you from accepting unfavorable terms while remaining flexible enough to explore creative solutions that might be better than your alternatives.
When to use: When Ali needs to help a negotiator establish their walkaway point or evaluate whether a proposed deal is worth accepting.
alternativespreparationleveragepower_dynamics
Coaching Move Develop BATNA before negotiating
Conduct vigorous exploration of what you will do if no agreement is reached. This involves three steps: (1) invent a list of possible actions if negotiations fail, (2) improve promising ideas into practical alternatives, and (3) select the most attractive option. Having a concrete BATNA significantly strengthens your negotiating position and confidence.
When to use: When Ali is coaching preparation phase or when a negotiator seems uncertain about their walk-away options.
preparationalternativesleverage
Coaching Move Avoid rigid bottom lines
Bottom lines are predetermined positions you refuse to change, which prevents you from learning during negotiation and inhibits creative problem-solving. They are often set too high (due to optimistic family discussions) or too low, and they shut down exploration of multi-variable solutions that could better serve your interests.
When to use: When Ali detects a negotiator is anchored to an inflexible position that prevents creative agreement-building.
preparationcreativitypower_dynamics
Coaching Move Use trip wire as early warning system
A trip wire is an agreement threshold that is better than your BATNA but not ideal. When a proposal approaches this threshold, pause negotiation to reassess rather than accept worse terms. This provides margin for movement and gives mediators room to work while protecting you from gradual degradation of terms.
When to use: When Ali wants to help a negotiator set protective guardrails without the rigidity of a bottom line.
preparationalternativesleverage
Framework Negotiating power determined by BATNA attractiveness
True negotiating power comes not from wealth, connections, or physical strength, but from how attractive your alternative to agreement is. The party with the better BATNA has more power because they can more easily walk away. Wealth and resources only create power if converted into a genuinely attractive alternative.
When to use: When Ali helps a negotiator understand their actual power in a negotiation or explains why they feel weak despite apparent advantages.

A wealthy tourist shopping for a brass pot has less negotiating power than a poor vendor who knows alternative buyers exist. The vendor's attractive alternative (selling to someone else) gives him power despite lower wealth. The tourist's wealth only helps if converted into knowledge of comparable pots available elsewhere.
When to use: When Ali wants to illustrate how formal power differs from negotiating power or help a negotiator understand why they're struggling despite advantages.

If your BATNA is weaker than they think, keep it confidential. Strategic disclosure of a strong alternative increases their incentive to reach favorable agreement.

Framework BATNA vs. arbitrary bottom line comparison
Unlike bottom lines which are inflexible and arbitrarily set, BATNA is concrete, measurable, and flexible. BATNA allows exploration of creative multi-variable solutions (e.g., lower price with first refusal rights, delayed closing, storage rights). BATNA measures against what you'll actually do, not what you 'ought' to get.
When to use: When Ali explains why BATNA is superior to bottom-line thinking or helps a negotiator shift from rigid to flexible protection strategies.
preparationalternativescreativity
Coaching Move Address aggregated alternative illusions
Negotiators often view alternatives in aggregate (California, going south, school, writing, farming, Paris) making their combined appeal seem greater than negotiating. But you cannot choose all of them—only one. Evaluate each realistic alternative individually to accurately assess your true BATNA.
When to use: When Ali helps a negotiator realistically assess their alternatives instead of psychologically inflating them.

Coaching Move Negotiate on merits when facing powerful opposition
When the other side has greater muscle or resources, do not engage in a direct power contest. Instead, establish principle as the governing framework. Having a strong BATNA allows you to negotiate on merits rather than capitulating to their power, because you have a credible walk-away option.
When to use: When Ali coaches a negotiator facing apparent power imbalance to shift toward principled negotiation.

When to use: When Ali helps a negotiator recognize that walking away is the right outcome rather than forcing agreement.

Coaching Move Strengthen confidence through BATNA clarity
Knowing your BATNA increases negotiating confidence because you have a concrete answer to 'what if negotiations fail.' This confidence makes it easier to break off negotiations if needed and allows you to present your interests more forcefully. The greater your willingness to walk away, the more effectively you negotiate.

Quote BATNA as standard for agreement measurement

Coaching Move Develop BATNA in three operational stages
Stage 1: Invent possible actions if no agreement reached. Stage 2: Improve promising ideas into practical alternatives (e.g., turn 'look in Chicago' into actual job offers). Stage 3: Select the single best option you'd actually pursue. Each stage requires concrete work, not wishful thinking.
When to use: When Ali provides step-by-step guidance for developing a comprehensive BATNA.

Coaching Move Understand BATNA vs. bottom line costs

BATNAs remain flexible and allow exploration of tailor-made solutions (e.g., lower price but with storage rights, first refusal, delayed closing). BATNA-based negotiation is more adaptive and creative.

Explore alternatives with other parties to create natural time pressure and urgency for the current negotiation. Framework Four personal ethics questions for negotiation
To determine what constitutes good faith negotiation and proper behavior, ask yourself: (1) Is this an approach I would use with a good friend or family member? (2) Would I be embarrassed if my actions appeared in newspapers? (3) In literature, would this conduct be more appropriate for a hero or villain? These questions illuminate your own values rather than imposing external judgment.
When to use: When you're uncertain whether a tactic is ethically appropriate or when deciding how to respond to questionable tactics from the other side.

Coaching Move Establish ground rules at negotiation start
Early in the negotiation, explicitly discuss the rules of engagement with the other side. Ask whether both parties are trying to reach a wise agreement efficiently, or whether you're playing 'hard bargaining' where stubbornness wins. This prevents misunderstandings about expectations and negotiation style.

Coaching Move Don't be a victim of dirty tactics
When facing improper or bad faith tactics from the other side, be prepared to fight back with equal firmness. You can be just as firm or firmer than they are. It is easier to defend principle than an illegitimate tactic. Make clear you won't accept behavior you would consider unfair if used against you.

Framework When positional bargaining makes sense
Positional bargaining can be appropriate in limited contexts: single-issue negotiations among strangers where transaction costs are high, parties are protected by competitive opportunities, and the outcome matters less than efficiency. However, be prepared to switch to principled negotiation if discussions bog down.
When to use: When evaluating whether to use positional or principled negotiation approaches given the specific negotiation context.

Coaching Move Evaluate importance of avoiding arbitrary outcomes
Consider how much you care about finding an answer to the problem that makes sense on the merits rather than through arbitrary haggling. Higher stakes negotiations, precedent-setting deals, and complex technical issues all justify moving away from positional bargaining toward principled negotiation.
When to use: When deciding whether the effort of principled negotiation is worth the investment given the importance and stakes of the deal.

Coaching Move Assess relationship importance before choosing approach
If the other side is a valued customer, client, or ongoing partner, maintaining the relationship may be more important than winning any single deal. This doesn't mean being less persistent about your interests, but it argues against high-risk tactics like threats or ultimatums. Negotiation on the merits helps you avoid choosing between giving in or damaging the relationship.
When to use: When evaluating negotiation approach with parties you'll likely encounter again or whose reputation matters to your future business.

Coaching Move Consider negotiation complexity when choosing method
Complex subject matter calls for careful analysis of interests and creative option-building rather than positional bargaining. The more complex the issues, the more important it becomes to engage in joint problem-solving and exploration of underlying interests rather than haggling over positions.
When to use: When facing a negotiation with multiple variables, interdependencies, or technical complexity.

Coaching Move Account for other side's negotiation expectations
Understand the other side's history and expectations about how negotiations should proceed. Coaching Move Time principled negotiation before positional bargaining
Positional bargaining does the least harm if it comes after you have identified each other's interests, invented options for mutual gain, and discussed relevant standards of fairness. This sequencing prevents bargaining from inhibiting the discovery of joint gains and prevents leaving value on the table.

Framework How to handle different fairness standards
When parties have different standards of fairness, agreement on the 'best' standard is not necessary. Using external standards improves outcomes by producing wiser results than arbitrary haggling, reducing the cost of backing down, and allowing comparison of relative persuasiveness. Standards are more persuasive when directly on point, widely accepted, and immediately relevant to time/place/circumstance.
When to use: When the other side advances a fairness standard different from yours and you need to find common ground or narrow disagreement.

Coaching Move Use fair procedures when standards remain contested
When standards have been refined and it's difficult to argue that one is more applicable than another, resort to fair procedures to settle remaining differences. Options include flipping a coin, using an arbitrator, splitting the difference, or other neutral methods that both sides perceive as legitimate.
When to use: When you've narrowed disagreement using standards but parties remain deadlocked on which standard applies.

Coaching Move Analyze costs before accepting unfair windfall
When you have the opportunity to gain more than you can justify as fair, carefully weigh the benefits against potential costs before accepting it. Consider: How much is the difference worth? Coaching Move Consider fairness for durability of agreements
If the other side later concludes an agreement is unfair, they may be unwilling to carry it out or may repudiate it before finalization. Courts may refuse to enforce 'unconscionable' agreements. An overly favorable tentative agreement is worthless if the other side abandons it. Fair dealing protects agreement durability.
When to use: When evaluating whether to press for maximum advantage versus ensuring the other side will actually honor the agreement.

Coaching Move Protect reputation for fair dealing
A well-established reputation for fair dealing is an extraordinary asset that opens up creative agreements impossible without trust. Such a reputation is much easier to destroy than build. Consider whether the immediate gain from unfair dealing is worth the long-term cost to your negotiation reputation.

Coaching Move Build working relationship independent of outcomes
Create a working relationship with the other side that can exist whether you agree or disagree on specific issues. The more seriously you disagree, the more important this becomes. A good working relationship can cope with differences and cannot be built through appeasement or ignoring disagreements.

Coaching Move Avoid appeasement for future cooperation
Making unjustified concessions now to maintain relationship will not create willingness to cooperate in the future. The other side will likely conclude that stubbornness works and expect the same dynamic in future negotiations. Principled firmness, not appeasement, builds the foundation for healthy ongoing relationships.

Coaching Move Address people problems directly in negotiation
People problems often require more attention than substantive issues. Do not sweep people problems under the rug or ignore how you're treating the other side. Defensive and reactive behavior is a primary reason many negotiations fail when agreement would make sense. Treat relationship and communication issues as central to negotiation success.

Framework Recognize negotiation as skill requiring practice
Reading about negotiation methods is like reading about physical exercise or sports—it provides direction and awareness but cannot make you skillful. No book can develop your negotiation skill; only doing it can. Expect to practice and gradually improve rather than expecting immediate mastery from theoretical knowledge.

Coaching Move Reframe negotiation as process, not winning
Don't evaluate negotiation success solely by asking 'Who won?' This question is inappropriate for important ongoing relationships, just as asking who's winning in a marriage means you've already lost the important negotiation about how you treat each other. The primary goal is winning the process negotiation—establishing how you'll work together on your differences.

Framework Principled negotiation enables having both outcomes
Principled negotiation allows you to achieve both getting what you deserve and being decent—you don't have to choose between satisfying your interests and maintaining integrity. This method should prove more efficient and less costly to human relationships than adversarial approaches while producing substantive outcomes as good or better over the long run.
When to use: When motivating use of principled negotiation by showing it achieves both substantive and relational goals simultaneously.

Coaching Move Remember common sense principles you already know

Learning involves connecting new frameworks to your existing knowledge and experience rather than discovering entirely new concepts.

Question Framework Does positional bargaining ever make sense?
Positional bargaining has limited appropriate use. Consider: How important is avoiding arbitrary outcomes? How complex are the issues? How important is maintaining the relationship? What are the other side's expectations and history? Where are you in the negotiation sequence? Use positional bargaining only in simple, transactional contexts with strangers where efficiency matters most.
When to use: When deciding whether to use positional or principled negotiation given the specific negotiation context and stakes.

Using external standards reduces the cost of backing down, narrows disagreement, and produces wiser outcomes than arbitrary haggling.

Ch 8. Taming the Hard Bargainer (What If They Use Dirty Tricks?)

53 items
A comprehensive catalog of dirty tactics and principled responses. Three categories: Deliberate deception (phony facts, ambiguous authority, dubious intentions), Psychological warfare (stressful environments, personal attacks, good-guy/bad-guy routines, threats), and Positional pressure (extreme demands, escalating demands, lock-in tactics, calculated delay, take-it-or-leave-it). The meta-principle: negotiate the rules of the game before you play the game.
Coaching Move × 39 Framework × 10 Example × 2 Quote × 2
Framework BATNA - Best Alternative to Negotiated Agreement
BATNA is the standard measure for evaluating any proposed agreement. It represents what you will actually do if negotiations fail, replacing arbitrary bottom lines. Your BATNA protects you from accepting unfavorable terms while preventing rejection of acceptable ones by providing a realistic, flexible benchmark based on actual alternatives.
When to use: When a user is uncertain about minimum acceptable terms or feels pressured to accept unfavorable offers, Ali should help them identify their true BATNA.
alternativespreparationpower_dynamicsleverage
Coaching Move Identify Your Real Alternative if Negotiation Fails
Ask yourself: 'What will I actually do if no agreement is reached?' rather than 'What should I get?' For a house sale, this might be renting it out, tearing it down, or letting it sit on the market. Being specific and realistic about this alternative clarifies what you should truly accept in negotiation.
When to use: At the preparation stage when Ali helps a user establish negotiation parameters and goals.
preparationalternativesleverage
Framework Three-Step BATNA Development Process
First, invent a list of possible actions if no agreement occurs. Second, improve promising ideas and convert them into practical, achievable alternatives (like securing a job offer elsewhere). Third, select which single option is best. This converts vague hopes into concrete, actionable alternatives that strengthen negotiating power.
When to use: When a user feels powerless or uncertain about their options, Ali should guide them through this systematic development process.
preparationalternativesleveragepower_dynamics
Quote Bottom Lines Sacrifice Flexibility and Creativity
'A bottom line—by its very nature rigid—is almost certain to be too rigid.' Bottom lines prevent you from learning during negotiation and block discovery of creative solutions that better satisfy both parties' interests by exploring multiple variables beyond price.
When to use: When a user mentions having a fixed bottom line or refuses to explore creative options, Ali should explain why flexibility serves them better.
creativitycommunicationalternativespower_dynamics
Coaching Move Avoid Anchoring Negotiation on Arbitrary Bottom Lines
Replace bottom lines with BATNA analysis. Don't negotiate based on what you 'ought' to get or what you hope for. Instead, ground your position in the concrete reality of what you'll do if talks fail, which is more likely to be realistic and protect your interests.
When to use: During preparation when Ali helps a user set negotiation targets and establish what they should and shouldn't accept.
preparationalternativesanchoringpower_dynamics
Example Bottom Line Set Too High Prevents Agreement
A family discussing house sale price at breakfast table: one suggests $100,000, another says $140,000, a third insists it's worth $200,000. No one objects to higher figures. The artificially inflated bottom line they adopt may prevent them from selling when they should, or they reject offers better than their actual alternative (renting).
When to use: When a user acknowledges they've set an arbitrary target without considering realistic alternatives, Ali can use this example to illustrate the danger.
preparationanchoringleverage
Coaching Move Formulate a Trip Wire for Early Warning
Identify one imperfect agreement that is better than your BATNA to serve as an early warning system. Before accepting anything worse than this trip-wire package, pause and reexamine. This provides a safety margin and leaves room for mediators while protecting you better than a rigid bottom line.
When to use: When Ali helps a user establish safety parameters before negotiating, as a more flexible alternative to bottom lines.
preparationpower_dynamicsleverage
Framework Power Comes from Your BATNA, Not Your Resources
Negotiating power depends primarily on how attractive each side's alternative to agreement is, not on wealth, connections, or physical strength. A wealthy tourist negotiating for a pot is powerless without knowing alternative sources. A person with multiple job offers negotiates salary far more effectively than one with only uncertain leads.
When to use: When a user feels intimidated by the other side's apparent resources or authority, Ali should reframe power as BATNA-dependent.
power_dynamicsleveragerelationship
Example Small Town Increased Factory Tax Through Strong BATNA
A small town raised a corporation's annual 'goodwill' payment from $300,000 to $2,300,000 by developing a credible BATNA: expanding town limits and taxing the factory at residential rates ($2,500,000). The corporation, though economically powerful and committed to staying, had no developed alternative, making the town's negotiating power superior.
When to use: When a user faces a seemingly more powerful opponent, Ali can use this example to show how BATNA development creates unexpected leverage.
power_dynamicsleveragebusiness_deals
Coaching Move Convert Your Resources into Better BATNA
Apply your knowledge, time, money, people, and connections to develop the best independent solution if negotiations fail—this is more effective than relying on inherent resources. A wealthy person should invest in market research, a job seeker should develop multiple offers, a community group should prepare legal action.
When to use: When a user has resources but feels powerless in negotiation, Ali should redirect them to develop better alternatives.
leveragepower_dynamicspreparationalternatives
Coaching Move Gain Confidence and Willingness to Walk Away
Knowing your BATNA in advance gives you additional confidence and willingness to break off negotiations. The easier you can walk away, the more forcefully you can present your interests and basis for agreement. Walking away becomes a realistic option, not a failure.
When to use: When a user shows anxiety about negotiations or feels trapped into accepting bad deals, Ali should emphasize how BATNA creates genuine options.
confidencepower_dynamicsleveragecommunication
Coaching Move Selectively Disclose Your BATNA to the Other Side
Disclose your BATNA if it's extremely attractive or if they underestimate your alternatives—doing so strengthens your position. But if your BATNA appears worse than they think, keep it hidden to avoid weakening your hand. Strategic disclosure depends on their likely perception.
When to use: During negotiation when a user is deciding what information to share about their alternatives and options.
communicationpower_dynamicsleverageinformation_gathering
Coaching Move Analyze the Other Side's BATNA and Expectations
Learn what alternatives the other side has available if agreement isn't reached. They may be unduly optimistic or viewing their options in the aggregate rather than realistically. Understanding their BATNA helps you estimate what outcomes are realistic and where they may have unrealistic expectations.
When to use: During information gathering and opening stages, Ali should guide users to research and understand the other party's alternatives.
information_gatheringpower_dynamicsleveragecommunication
Coaching Move Lower Unrealistic Expectations in the Other Side
If the other side overestimates their BATNA, work to correct their perception. You might provide information, introduce realistic constraints, or even strengthen their actual alternatives. If their BATNA is too attractive relative to any fair agreement, change what you can about their situation to create incentive for negotiation.
When to use: When Ali recognizes the other party has unrealistic expectations about what they can achieve without agreement.
power_dynamicsleveragecommunicationinformation_gathering
Framework Sometimes No Agreement Is the Best Outcome
If both sides have attractive BATNAs, the best outcome may be not reaching agreement. A successful negotiation is one where both parties amicably discover that advancing their respective interests means each should look elsewhere rather than continue negotiating.
When to use: When a user is frustrated with slow progress or Ali determines the negotiation may not serve the user's interests.
alternativespower_dynamicsleverageclosing
Coaching Move Protect Yourself When Emotionally Invested
When you're heavily invested in reaching agreement (like selling a house after owning it a year), you face danger of being too accommodating. The psychological pressure to 'just agree and end this' becomes persuasive. Your BATNA and trip wire protect you against desperation-driven poor decisions.
When to use: When Ali detects emotional investment or desperation in a user's approach to negotiation.
emotionspower_dynamicspreparationleverage
Coaching Move Avoid Psychological Errors in Assessing Alternatives
Don't aggregate your alternatives mentally (California, teaching, farming, Paris, etc.) and assume you'll have all of them if negotiations fail—you can only choose one. Also don't be overly pessimistic about BATNA consequences. Carefully assess the single most realistic alternative and its actual costs.
When to use: When a user seems to be either unrealistically optimistic or pessimistic about their alternatives.
alternativespreparationpower_dynamicsemotions
Coaching Move Establish Agent Authority Using BATNA and Trip Wire
Instruct agents or representatives with BATNA-based guidance: 'Get the best agreement you can, but don't settle for less than [trip wire standard], and report to me before going below [that level].' This prevents agents from being split off by pressure or better offers while maintaining flexibility.
When to use: When a user is employing agents, lawyers, brokers or negotiating as a coalition, Ali should recommend authorization frameworks based on BATNA.
team_negotiationpower_dynamicsleveragepreparation
Coaching Move Prepare for Power Imbalances by Negotiating on Merits
When facing a stronger opponent with greater physical or economic power, don't turn negotiation into a contest of power. Instead, establish principle and merit-based standards as the basis for discussion. Your BATNA research supports this merit-based approach.
When to use: When a user faces a significantly more powerful negotiating partner and needs strategic positioning.

Framework Negotiating Power Sources: Merits vs. Muscle
When the other side has muscle (power, resources, strength), establish as large a role as possible for principle and merit-based standards in the negotiation. To the extent they rely on power and you introduce merit-based criteria, you improve your relative negotiating position.
When to use: When Ali helps a user strategically position themselves against a more powerful opponent.

Coaching Move Avoid Misreading Your Own Bargaining Position
Carefully examine whether you're truly in a weak position or whether you haven't fully developed your BATNA. Many people assume powerlessness when they actually have unexplored alternatives. Before accepting a weak position, invest effort in developing your alternatives.
When to use: When a user presents themselves as powerless without having thoroughly explored alternatives, Ali should challenge this assessment.

Coaching Move Create fading opportunity for other side
Develop alternative options outside the current negotiation to create natural time pressure. Explore talks with third parties or identify objective external deadlines such as tax dates, annual meetings, contract end dates, or legislative sessions. This creates urgency without explicit ultimatums.
When to use: When Ali detects the other party is stalling or delaying tactics, or when the user needs leverage without appearing aggressive.

Coaching Move Distinguish negotiation from take-it-or-leave-it
Recognize that 'take it or leave it' statements are not negotiation but rather efficient transactional offers. After long negotiations, phrasing a final offer politely as 'take it or leave it' can be appropriate, but understand this ends interactive decision-making.

Coaching Move Ignore ultimatums and keep negotiating
When faced with a 'take it or leave it' ultimatum, continue talking as if you didn't hear it or change the subject by introducing alternative solutions. This avoids accepting a false ultimatum while maintaining dialogue.

Provide face-saving ways for the other side to move away from their ultimatum by pointing to changed circumstances. For example, reference new information or developments that justify revisiting the 'final' offer.

Framework Self-reflection questions on good faith
Evaluate whether tactics are appropriate by asking: Would I use this with a good friend or family member? Would I be embarrassed if this appeared in newspapers? Would this be more fitting for a hero or villain in literature? These questions illuminate your own values about ethical negotiation.

Coaching Move Establish rules of engagement at start
Early in negotiation, explicitly ask the other side about the rules of engagement: 'Are we both trying to reach a wise agreement quickly, or are we playing hard bargaining?' This clarifies expectations and can reset tone toward principled negotiation.

Coaching Move Don't be a victim of dirty tactics
Be prepared to defend yourself against dirty bargaining tactics with equal firmness. Defending principle is easier than defending illegitimate tactics, giving you psychological and practical advantage.

Framework Consider when positional bargaining makes sense
Evaluate whether to use positional bargaining by considering: importance of avoiding arbitrary outcomes, complexity of issues, importance of maintaining relationships, other party's expectations, and where you are in the negotiation. Principled negotiation yields better outcomes in most cases.

Coaching Move Avoid positional bargaining for complex issues
The more complex the subject matter, avoid positional haggling. Complexity requires careful analysis of interests, creative option invention, and joint problem-solving rather than position trading.

Coaching Move Prioritize relationships in ongoing dealings
If the other side is a valued customer, client, or someone you'll negotiate with repeatedly, maintaining the relationship may be more important than any single deal outcome. Avoid tactics like threats or ultimatums that risk relationship damage.

Coaching Move Change gears if negotiation bogs down
In single-issue negotiations among strangers, simple positional haggling may work. But if discussion stalls, be prepared to shift strategy: start clarifying underlying interests instead.

Coaching Move Account for entrenched adversarial culture
In labor-management and other contexts with long histories of positional bargaining, parties may see the other as enemies and ignore mutual costs. Set realistic timelines for change that may span multiple negotiations. Change takes time even when both sides want it.

Coaching Move Apply standards after exploring interests
Positional bargaining does least harm when it comes after you have identified each other's interests, invented options for mutual gain, and discussed standards of fairness. Save positions for later in negotiation.

Framework Use external standards when fairness differs
When parties disagree on fairness standards, external standards improve outcomes in three ways: they're wiser than arbitrary results, reduce costs of backing down by following principle rather than conceding to demands, and some standards are more persuasive than others.
When to use: When Ali detects parties have conflicting views on what's fair and needs to bridge the gap.

Coaching Move Evaluate standard applicability factors
When choosing among fairness standards, select the one most directly on point, most widely accepted, and most immediately relevant in terms of time, place and circumstance. More persuasive standards are those meeting these criteria.

Coaching Move Agreement on best standard unnecessary
Parties don't need to agree on which standard is 'best' to use standards effectively. Differences in values, culture, and experience naturally lead to disagreement, but standards can still narrow the range of disagreement and expand potential agreement area.
When to use: When Ali detects parties are stuck debating which standard is most appropriate rather than using multiple standards productively.

Coaching Move Use fair procedures for remaining gaps
When standards have been refined to the point that it's hard to argue one is more applicable than another, explore tradeoffs or resort to fair procedures: coin flip, arbitration, or splitting the difference.

Coaching Move Use fairness to get what you deserve
Using independent standards helps you get what you deserve and protects you from being taken advantage of. This is not about being good for goodness' sake, but about effective negotiation strategy.

Coaching Move Ask for justified amounts not excessive ones
Don't assume you should ask for more than you can justify as fair just because you can. Regularly persuading others to give you more than is fair carries long-term costs that typically outweigh short-term gains.

Coaching Move Don't ignore people problems in negotiation
Don't sweep people problems under the rug. People problems often require more attention than substantive ones. Human propensity for defensive and reactive behavior causes many negotiations to fail when agreement would make sense. Ignoring how you treat the other side is perilous.

Coaching Move Build working relationship independent of agreement
Develop ability to work well with someone you disagree with. Good working relationships cope with differences and cannot be bought through unjustified concessions or pretending disagreements don't exist. Appeasement typically doesn't work.

Coaching Move Avoid belief that concessions create reciprocity
Making an unjustified concession now doesn't make future dealings easier. The other side interprets it as weakness to exploit—they expect you to give in again if they're stubborn enough. Reciprocal concession thinking is flawed.

Quote Don't ask who is winning in marriage-like negotiations
Asking 'Who's winning?' is inappropriate for marriage or ongoing negotiations, just as it would be inappropriate for a marriage. If you ask that question, you've already lost the important negotiation—the one about what kind of relationship and process you're establishing.
When to use: When Ali wants to reframe the user's perspective away from zero-sum thinking in ongoing relationships.
relationshipstrategycommunicationpower_dynamics
Framework Win the process negotiation first
The primary goal should be winning a better process for dealing with differences—how you engage, treat each other, and address shared and differing interests. Winning on merits matters, but losing the process negotiation is worse.

Coaching Move Principled negotiation produces better outcomes long-term
Both theory and experience suggest that principled negotiation will produce substantive outcomes as good as or better than other strategies over the long run, while being more efficient and less costly to relationships.

Coaching Move Get both fair results and decent treatment
You can achieve both getting what you deserve and being decent. Changing negotiating habits to disentangle emotions from merits and involve others in problem-solving isn't easy, but allows you to avoid choosing between satisfaction of just winning or just being good.
When to use: When Ali wants to resolve the user's perceived dilemma between being tough and being fair.

Never Split the Difference Tactical / FBI

Chris Voss with Tahl Raz (2016)
Chris Voss's FBI hostage negotiation playbook adapted for business and everyday life. Rejects the Harvard model's assumption that people are rational actors. Instead, Voss argues negotiation is fundamentally about emotions — and the negotiator who can identify, influence, and manage emotions (theirs and the counterpart's) wins. Each chapter introduces a specific technique field-tested in kidnapping crises and high-stakes business deals.

Ch 1. The New Rules

20 items
Voss's origin story: how the FBI's Crisis Negotiation Unit evolved from simple tactical responses to a sophisticated system of emotional intelligence. Challenges the rational-agent assumptions behind Getting to Yes. Introduces the core premise: negotiation is not about logic or compromise — it's about emotional discovery. The person across the table is not a problem to be solved, but a human to be understood.
Coaching Move × 5 Framework × 3 Example × 4 Quote × 8
Coaching Move Calibrated Questions
Ask open-ended questions without fixed answers that shift control to the counterpart while constraining their options. Examples include "How am I supposed to do that?" or "How can I know he's alive?" These questions make counterparts feel in control while forcing them to solve your problems, buying you time and revealing their constraints.
When to use: When facing aggressive demands, threats, or when you need to understand the other side's reasoning without appearing confrontational.
communicationpower_dynamicsinformation_gatheringtactics
Coaching Move Illusion of Control Strategy
Give your counterpart the illusion that they have power and control by letting them answer questions and provide solutions. This psychological positioning makes them feel dominant while you guide the negotiation through strategic questioning. It prevents them from feeling cornered or defensive.
When to use: When you need the other side to feel empowered and cooperate rather than dig in or escalate demands.
power_dynamicsrelationshipemotionscommunication
Coaching Move Passive-Aggressive Questioning
Repeatedly ask the same 3-4 open-ended questions over and over, which makes counterparts exhaust themselves answering and eventually concede. The repetition wears them down emotionally while maintaining a surface-level polite demeanor. This approach is particularly effective against prepared scripts and logical arguments.
When to use: When facing counterparts with rehearsed arguments or when you need to wear down resistance without direct confrontation.
communicationemotionsdifficult_peopleleverage
Coaching Move Seed Warmth with Apologies and Names
Use apologies and the counterpart's first name to complicate aggressive tactics and build rapport. This humanizes the interaction and makes it harder for the other side to maintain a purely adversarial stance. It shifts the dynamic from transactional to relational.
When to use: When facing aggressive counterparts or when you need to de-escalate tension and build trust.
relationshipemotionscommunicationopening
Framework System 1 vs System 2 Thinking Model
Kahneman's framework identifies System 1 as fast, instinctive, emotional thinking that drives behavior, and System 2 as slow, deliberative, logical thinking. System 1 is more influential and feeds System 2 responses. To negotiate effectively, influence the counterpart's System 1 emotional reactions through strategic framing and question delivery, which will then shape their System 2 rational justifications.
When to use: When designing your communication strategy, choose language and framing that affects emotional responses first, knowing rationality will follow.
emotionspsychologycommunicationpower_dynamics
Framework Problem-Solving vs Emotional Reality Approach
Traditional negotiation theory (Getting to Yes) assumes rational problem-solving can resolve conflicts. However, real-world hostage and crisis negotiations reveal that emotional factors dominate—you cannot reason with someone who believes they're a messiah. Effective negotiation requires emotional intelligence and understanding irrational motivations, not just logical analysis.
When to use: When assessing whether your counterpart will respond to logical arguments or if you need to address underlying emotional/psychological drivers.
emotionspsychologydifficult_peoplepreparation
Framework Cognitive Bias Awareness Framework
Recognize that humans are subject to 150+ cognitive biases including Framing Effect (same choice valued differently based on presentation), Prospect Theory (taking unwarranted risks to avoid losses), and Loss Aversion (acting more to prevent losses than achieve gains). Understanding these biases allows negotiators to frame proposals strategically and predict counterpart behavior.
When to use: When structuring offers, framing proposals, or predicting how the other side will respond to different options.
psychologyanchoringconcessionscommunication
Example Harvard Negotiation Course Role Play Success
Voss negotiated against Andy, a Harvard Law student, using only calibrated questions like "How am I supposed to do that?" while Andy used cutting-edge rational techniques and logic traps. Voss extracted every dollar Andy had in reserve, leaving him humiliated. The instructor noted Voss's questions made students falter because they revealed the unfairness and dishonesty of their own offers.
When to use: When explaining why emotional/psychological tactics outperform pure rational argumentation, or when coaching on the power of simple questioning.
communicationpower_dynamicsleverageexamples
Example Harvard Professor Role Play with Mnookin and Blum
Voss was set up by Harvard Negotiation Project director Robert Mnookin and international negotiator Gabriella Blum in a mock kidnapping scenario demanding $1 million. When they used aggressive bulldozer tactics, Voss responded with calibrated questions about proof of life and logistics. Both professors became frustrated and unable to proceed, eventually conceding that "the FBI might have something to teach us."
When to use: When demonstrating that FBI field-tested techniques work against highly trained and intelligent counterparts, or when explaining why questioning beats aggression.
leveragedifficult_peoplepower_dynamicsexamples
Example Jacksonville Airport Hijacking (Downs v. United States)
In 1971, hijacker George Giffe Jr. held a plane with hostages. Two hostages had convinced Giffe to release them on the Jacksonville tarmac, representing successful negotiation progress. However, impatient FBI agents shot out the engine, escalating the situation and causing Giffe to kill the remaining hostages and himself. The resulting court decision established that "a reasonable attempt at negotiations must be made prior to a tactical intervention," catalyzing modern hostage negotiation practices.
When to use: When explaining the historical shift from force-based to negotiation-based crisis resolution, or when coaching on the dangers of impatience.
leverageethicspreparationexamples
Example Ruby Ridge and Waco Failures
The 1992 Ruby Ridge siege and 1993 Waco Branch Davidian compound siege were "fatally disastrous" hostage negotiations that revealed Getting to Yes's inadequacy. These incidents proved that rational problem-solving fails with irrational actors (like someone who believes he's a messiah). The failures led to the creation of the FBI's Critical Incident Response Group and a complete rethinking of negotiation approach.
When to use: When illustrating the limitations of purely rational negotiation frameworks or when discussing the need for emotional intelligence in crisis situations.
emotionsdifficult_peoplepsychologyexamples
Quote Negotiation is Not Rational Problem-Solving
"I mean, have you ever tried to devise a mutually beneficial win-win solution with a guy who thinks he's the messiah?" This captures why traditional negotiation theory fails in real-world crises—emotional and psychological factors dominate over rational joint problem-solving.
When to use: When explaining why Getting to Yes fails with difficult counterparts or when coaching on the need for emotional intelligence over pure logic.
emotionspsychologydifficult_people
Quote Humans Are Irrational, Not Rational Actors
"Without a deep understanding of human psychology, without the acceptance that we are all crazy, irrational, impulsive, emotionally driven animals, all the raw intelligence and mathematical logic in the world is little help in the fraught, shifting interplay of two people negotiating." This encapsulates Voss's core philosophy about why traditional rational approaches fail.
When to use: When explaining the fundamental principle that negotiation requires emotional intelligence and understanding irrationality, not just logical analysis.
psychologyemotionspreparationphilosophy
Quote Feeling is a Form of Thinking
"Feeling, they discovered, is a form of thinking." This Kahneman insight establishes that emotions aren't obstacles to rationality—they're foundational to how the mind processes information and makes decisions.
When to use: When reframing emotions as legitimate drivers of decision-making rather than barriers to overcome.
psychologyemotionscommunication
Quote System 1 Guides System 2
"System 1's inchoate beliefs, feelings, and impressions are the main sources of the explicit beliefs and deliberate choices of System 2. They're the spring that feeds the river." This explains why emotional positioning must precede logical arguments in negotiation.
When to use: When coaching on why framing and emotional appeals must come before rational arguments, or when designing communication strategy.
psychologyemotionscommunication
Quote Kidnapping is Negotiated Business
"What was the difference between bank robbers who took hostages and CEOs who used hardball tactics to drive down the price of a billion-dollar acquisition? After all, kidnappers are just businessmen trying to get the best price." This illustrates that hostage negotiation tactics apply universally across all negotiation domains.
When to use: When explaining why FBI crisis negotiation techniques are relevant to business and everyday negotiations.
leveragepower_dynamicsbusiness_deals
Quote Experiential Learning Beats Theory
"Our techniques were the products of experiential learning; they were developed by agents in the field, negotiating through crisis and sharing stories of what succeeded and what failed. It was an iterative process, not an intellectual one... Our tools had to work, because if they didn't someone died." This emphasizes that field-tested tactics under life-or-death pressure trump ivory tower theory.
When to use: When validating practical experience over academic theory, or when explaining why FBI methods proved superior at Harvard.
preparationleveragephilosophy
Quote Negotiation is Unpredictable, Not Scripted
"In the real world negotiation is far too unpredictable and complex for that. You may have to do a then d, and then maybe q." This critiques the rigid process-driven approach of traditional negotiation theory in favor of adaptive, responsive tactics.
When to use: When coaching on flexibility and adaptation rather than following fixed scripts or predetermined sequences.
communicationpreparationpower_dynamics
Quote Getting to Yes Assumption Was Wrong
"Their core assumption was that the emotional brain—that animalistic, unreliable, and irrational beast—could be overcome through a more rational, joint problem-solving mindset." This identifies the fundamental flaw in Getting to Yes: it assumes emotions can be suppressed rather than managed.
When to use: When explaining limitations of traditional negotiation frameworks or when pivoting to emotion-centered approaches.
psychologyemotionspreparation
Coaching Move Simple Questions Defeat Complex Preparation
A few simple, well-timed open-ended questions can dismantle elaborate logical arguments and prepared scripts. The power comes not from complexity but from psychological insight—questions that trigger System 1 emotional responses that undermine System 2 rational defenses. Simplicity forces counterparts into unscripted, reactive thinking.
When to use: When facing highly prepared opponents or when you need to break through polished arguments and forced positions.

Ch 2. Be a Mirror

53 items
The simplest and most immediately useful technique: mirroring. Repeat the last 1-3 words (or critical words) of what someone just said. This triggers a deep instinct to elaborate, creating rapport and encouraging the other side to reveal more than they intended. Combined with late-night FM DJ voice and tactical silence, mirroring is Voss's go-to opening move in any negotiation.
Coaching Move × 32 Framework × 13 Example × 6 Quote × 2
Framework Assumptions Blind, Hypotheses Guide
Great negotiators hold multiple hypotheses simultaneously and use new information to test and refine them rather than clinging to initial assumptions. People often make assumptions before meeting counterparts and ignore perceptions that contradict their beliefs. Smart people sometimes struggle as negotiators because they assume they have nothing to discover. Success requires approaching negotiations with a mindset of discovery, remaining emotionally open to possibilities.
When to use: When Ali detects that the user is making premature judgments about their counterpart or seems overly confident in their initial assessment of the situation.
information_gatheringcommunicationpreparation
Coaching Move Question Your Own Assumptions First
Before engaging in negotiation, examine what you think you know and be prepared to discard those beliefs when new information arrives. Assumptions create a 'flawed version' of reality that prevents you from seeing what's actually happening. Great negotiators question assumptions that others accept on faith or arrogance. This intellectual agility allows you to adapt as situations evolve.
When to use: When Ali needs to help the user avoid being blindsided by unexpected counterpart behavior or when the user seems stuck in an outdated understanding of the negotiation.
preparationinformation_gatheringpower_dynamics
Example Chris Watts Bank Robbery Case: Misinformation Detection
In a 1993 Brooklyn bank robbery, the lead hostage-taker claimed he had multiple volatile co-conspirators from different countries and kept referring to 'we/they' and others making decisions. Investigation later revealed he had only one other robber (who was tricked into it) and a getaway driver. His overuse of pronouns about others was a tell that he was less important than he claimed. The false surrender information was actually an escape plan.
When to use: When Ali wants to illustrate how counterparts use pronouns and information as manipulation tactics, or when teaching users to detect inconsistencies in a counterpart's story.
information_gatheringcommunicationpower_dynamicsdifficult_people
Coaching Move Monitor Pronoun Usage for Power Clues
Pay attention to how often your counterpart uses personal pronouns like 'we,' 'they,' 'me,' and 'I.' When someone downplays their own importance by constantly attributing decisions to others, they may actually be more important or more in control than they claim. Conversely, excessive use of 'I' might indicate someone is trying to position themselves as the decision-maker.
When to use: When Ali is helping the user read between the lines of what a counterpart is saying, particularly when dealing with someone who seems evasive or is claiming powerlessness.
information_gatheringcommunicationpower_dynamicsdifficult_people
Coaching Move Recognize When Counterpart Tactics Create Confusion
Hostage-takers and difficult negotiators often use multiple tactics simultaneously: putting people on speaker then denying it, claiming they can't control co-conspirators, using smoke screens, and changing topics or hanging up abruptly. These are deliberate strategies to confuse the other side and buy time. Recognizing this pattern helps you stay calm and not take the behavior personally.
When to use: When the user's counterpart is being evasive, inconsistent, or seemingly irrational, and the user is becoming frustrated or confused.
difficult_peoplepower_dynamicsemotions
Framework Calm the Schizophrenic: Active Listening vs. Internal Debate
Most negotiators enter conversations preoccupied with their own arguments, creating a state of 'schizophrenia' where both sides are listening to internal voices rather than to each other. Research shows people can process only about seven pieces of information consciously at once. When you're not talking, you're thinking about your arguments; when you are talking, you're making them. The solution is to make the other person your sole focus, not your arguments.
When to use: When Ali detects the user is too focused on making their case or when the conversation seems stuck and unproductive due to both parties advocating rather than listening.
communicationrelationshipemotions
Coaching Move Prioritize Active Listening Over Argument Construction
Instead of thinking about what you're going to say next, make your sole focus the other person and what they have to say. This creates a powerful psychological shift. True active listening disarms counterparts and makes them feel safe. When people feel heard, the internal voice in their head quiets down, and they become more willing to share genuine information about what they want and need.
When to use: When Ali is coaching the user through the early stages of a negotiation or when the user seems to be talking too much and not learning enough about the counterpart.
communicationrelationshipemotionsinformation_gathering
Framework Distinguish Between Wants and Needs
Wants represent our aspirations and the illusion of control we maintain as negotiations begin. Needs imply survival and the minimum required to make us act—they make us vulnerable. Neither is the starting point; you begin with listening, validating emotions, and creating trust and safety. Only after establishing this foundation can you discover what counterparts truly need (monetarily, emotionally, or otherwise).
When to use: When Ali is helping the user move beyond surface-level demands to understand what will actually motivate their counterpart to agree.
information_gatheringemotionsrelationship
Coaching Move Slow Down to Calm Down
Going too fast is one of the most common mistakes negotiators make. When you move too quickly, people feel unheard and trust erodes. Slowing the process down also calms it emotionally. There's substantial research validating that passage of time is one of the most important tools available to negotiators. When someone is talking, they're not taking aggressive action—talking buys you safety and information.
When to use: When Ali detects that the user is pushing hard for a quick solution or when the negotiation seems to be escalating emotionally.
communicationemotionspower_dynamicsrelationship
Example Food Negotiation as a Delaying Tactic
During the bank robbery standoff, the hostage-taker brought up wanting food, which became its own negotiation. While discussing food delivery methods, the lead negotiator and team were actually buying time for investigators to identify the perpetrator, run vehicle registrations, and locate a witness who could identify the hostage-taker by voice. The counterpart kept changing their mind, creating smoke screens, but the delays worked to the negotiators' advantage.

When a counterpart stalls or creates delays through discussing tangential issues, they may be buying time for their own purposes. However, you can also use these delays strategically to gather information, run background checks, identify the true decision-makers, or prepare your team. Don't rush to end these delays; instead, use them productively.

Knowledge alone isn't power; using it strategically is.

Framework The Three Negotiator Voice Tones
There are three primary voice tones available to negotiators: (1) the late-night FM DJ voice—deep, soft, slow, and reassuring; (2) the positive/playful voice—easygoing and good-natured; and (3) the direct or assertive voice—which signals dominance. The assertive voice should be used rarely and strategically, as it typically triggers defensive responses. Most of the time, use the positive/playful or late-night FM DJ voices.
When to use: When coaching the user on how to modulate their communication style, or when they report difficulty getting their counterpart to open up.
communicationrelationshipemotions
Coaching Move Master the Late-Night FM DJ Voice
The late-night FM DJ voice is deep, soft, slow, and reassuring. It conveys calm and reason. This voice is particularly effective when you need to keep someone talking, disarm them, or help them feel safe enough to open up. It's especially useful when making a difficult statement or transition (like replacing another negotiator). The tone itself does much of the persuasion work, independent of the words used.
When to use: When Ali wants to help the user calm a tense conversation, make a difficult statement, or shift the emotional tone of a negotiation.
communicationemotionsrelationship
Coaching Move Use the Positive/Playful Voice as Your Default
The positive/playful voice should be your primary tool in negotiations. It projects an easygoing, good-natured demeanor. The key to this voice is relaxing and smiling while you talk—even on the phone, a smile has a tonal impact that the other person unconsciously perceives. This voice creates an atmosphere of lightness and encouragement, making people more willing to engage honestly.
When to use: When coaching the user through most negotiation interactions, particularly in early rapport-building phases.
communicationrelationshipemotions
Coaching Move Avoid the Assertive Voice Except in Rare Cases
The direct or assertive voice signals dominance and control. Using it is like 'slapping yourself in the face while trying to make progress.' Counterparts will either aggressively or passive-aggressively push back against attempts to control them. Reserve the assertive voice for very rare circumstances, and only when you've established enough rapport that it won't damage the relationship.
When to use: When the user seems to be defaulting to an aggressive or commanding tone, or when Ali detects they're trying to force compliance.
communicationpower_dynamicsemotions
Framework Voice as Neurological Influence Tool
Your voice is your most powerful tool in verbal communication. You can use it intentionally to reach into someone's brain and flip emotional switches—from distrusting to trusting, nervous to calm. Our brains process not just words and actions but also feelings, intentions, and social meaning of behavior on a mostly unconscious level. On a neurological level, we understand other minds through 'involuntary neurological telepathy'—we signal whether we're ready to play or fight, laugh or cry.
When to use: When explaining to the user why tone matters more than content in certain contexts, or when they're focused only on what to say rather than how to say it.
communicationemotionsrelationship
Coaching Move Focus on Demeanor Over Content in Early Stages
When deliberating on negotiating strategy, people tend to focus on what to say or do, but research shows it's how you 'are'—your general demeanor and delivery—that is both easiest to enact and most immediately effective as a mode of influence. Your tone, body language (even perceptible over the phone), and emotional state communicate before your words do. This is why how you say something often matters more than what you say.
When to use: When the user is overly focused on crafting the perfect argument or perfect words while neglecting their delivery and emotional presence.

Framework Mirror and Reflect Emotional Signals
Understanding that reflex emotional responses are involuntary and nearly automatic is critical to negotiation success. When we radiate warmth and acceptance, conversations flow. When we enter a space with comfort and enthusiasm, we attract people toward us. A smile on the street gets reflexively returned. These automatic, mirrored responses occur at a neurological level below conscious thought. Recognizing and leveraging this creates powerful dynamics in negotiation.
When to use: When explaining to the user why their emotional state and tone matter so much, or when they're skeptical that non-verbal communication affects negotiations.

Coaching Move Make Downward-Inflecting Statements Without Questioning Tone
When making a statement (not a question), use a downward-inflecting tone—one that lands with finality and calm authority. This is different from upward-inflecting questions that invite challenge. In the bank case, Chris Voss didn't say 'Is this going to be a problem?' but rather made the flat statement 'Joe's gone. This is Chris. You're talking to me now.' The delivery communicated calm certainty rather than uncertainty seeking approval.
When to use: When coaching the user to be more assertive in their statements, or when they're seeking permission/validation through upward-inflecting tones.

Coaching Move Establish Team Listening Structure for Complex Negotiations
The FBI uses teams of negotiators in standoffs because listening is harder than most people realize. Multiple sets of ears catch more information. With teams, one person can listen for content while another gauges mood, another listens for tells or inconsistencies. This distributed attention catches more than any individual can process alone, given research shows people consciously process only about seven pieces of information at once.
When to use: When the user is preparing for a high-stakes negotiation or when they have a team available and Ali is coaching on preparation strategy.

Coaching Move Assign Specific Listening Roles Within Your Team
If you have a negotiation team, assign specific roles: one person focuses on content/facts, another on the emotional state of the counterpart, another on inconsistencies or tells, and the primary negotiator focuses on keeping the conversation flowing. This prevents the cognitive overload that comes from trying to do everything at once and ensures multiple perspectives inform your strategy.

Framework The Mirroring Technique Foundation
Mirroring involves repeating back what people say to trigger their natural instinct to elaborate and sustain connection. This simple technique creates psychological rapport by making counterparts feel heard and understood. Research shows mirroring generates significantly better results than positive reinforcement alone.
When to use: Use this when Ali wants to explain the core mechanic of how mirroring works and why it's effective.
communicationrelationshipinformation_gathering
Coaching Move Let the Mirror Sit in Silence
After mirroring, you must pause and remain silent for at least four seconds to allow the technique to work. Immediately following up with additional questions or statements negates the mirror's effectiveness and gives counterparts an escape route. Silence creates psychological pressure that prompts elaboration and reveals information.
When to use: Surface this when Ali detects that the user is asking follow-up questions immediately after mirroring or showing impatience with pauses.
communicationinformation_gatheringpower_dynamics
Coaching Move Mirror with Inquisitive Tone and Intent
Deliver mirrors as genuine questions with downward inflection, signaling 'Please help me understand' rather than challenge or sarcasm. The tone should convey respect and concern for what the other person is saying. This transforms mirroring from a technique into an empathetic inquiry.
When to use: Use when Ali needs to coach on tone of voice and underlying intention behind mirroring statements.

Framework Four-Step Confrontation Without Confrontation
1) Use late-night FM DJ voice (calm, low, soothing). 2) Start with 'I'm sorry...' to show empathy. 3) Mirror the other person's statement back to them. 4) Silence for at least four seconds. 5) Repeat as needed. This approach allows you to disagree without being disagreeable and works especially well with aggressive or domineering personalities.
When to use: Surface this when Ali needs to provide a complete roadmap for handling difficult or confrontational counterparts.

Framework Distinguish Mirroring from Direct Questions
Asking 'What do you mean by that?' often incites irritation or defensiveness. Mirroring the statement instead gets the same clarity while signaling respect and concern. The mirror achieves understanding through empathetic repetition rather than challenging inquiry. This subtle distinction dramatically changes how counterparts respond.
