Ch 5. Trigger the Two Words — "That's Right"

21 items
The breakthrough moment in any negotiation: getting the other side to say "That's right." Not 'you're right' (which means they want you to go away) but 'that's right' — a genuine acknowledgment that you understand their world. Achieved through summarizing: paraphrasing their position + labeling their underlying emotions. Once they say 'that's right,' behavior change and deal-making become possible.
Coaching Move × 10 Framework × 2 Example × 4 Quote × 5
Framework Behavioral Change Stairway Model (BCSM)
A five-stage framework developed by the FBI's Crisis Negotiation Unit that guides negotiators from listening to influencing behavior: active listening → empathy → rapport → influence → behavioral change. Based on Carl Rogers' concept of unconditional positive regard, the model requires accepting the other party as they are before attempting to create lasting change. Real behavior change only occurs when someone reaches a breakthrough moment where unconditional positive regard is established.
When to use: Use this framework when coaching negotiators who want to create lasting behavioral change, not just temporary compliance. Most valuable when negotiating with resistant parties or entrenched positions.
emotionsrelationshipcommunicationleverage
Coaching Move Target 'That's Right' Not 'Yes'
The two words 'That's right' represent a far more powerful negotiation outcome than 'yes.' When someone says 'That's right,' they've internalized your summary and created their own mental realization without feeling they've given in. 'Yes' often leads nowhere and can be empty agreement. The key difference is ownership: 'That's right' signals genuine agreement and understanding, while 'yes' can be dismissed later.
When to use: Coach negotiators who are pursuing simple agreement. Redirect their focus to achieving genuine understanding and buy-in from the counterpart.
communicationclosingleverageemotions
Coaching Move Create a Summary to Trigger 'That's Right'
Construct a comprehensive summary combining paraphrasing (your own words recap of what they said) plus labeling (acknowledging the emotions underlying their position). The summary should fully articulate their world, concerns, and feelings without argument or disagreement. When done correctly, the only natural response is 'That's right,' as the counterpart feels truly understood.
When to use: Use when negotiations are deadlocked or when you need to reset the conversation and achieve genuine breakthrough. Most effective after extensive active listening.
communicationinformation_gatheringrelationshipemotions
Coaching Move Active Listening Arsenal: Six Tactical Moves
Deploy these six active listening techniques in sequence to soften resistance and build toward 'That's right': (1) Effective Pauses—use silence strategically to encourage continued talking and drain emotions; (2) Minimal Encouragers—simple phrases like 'Yes,' 'OK,' 'Uh-huh' to show attention; (3) Mirroring—repeat back what the counterpart said; (4) Labeling—name the feelings you observe ('It seems unfair'); (5) Paraphrasing—restate in your own words; (6) Summarize—combine paraphrasing + labeling for maximum impact.
When to use: Deploy these tactics when facing a rigid counterpart, resistance, or when you need to build rapport and understanding before moving to proposals or closing.
communicationrelationshipemotionsinformation_gathering
Coaching Move Distinguish 'That's Right' from 'You're Right'
'You're right' is a dismissive phrase people use to end unwanted conversation—it signals they want the person to leave them alone, not genuine agreement. When you hear 'You're right,' the other party hasn't embraced your point and will likely revert to their previous behavior. It's a polite exit, not a real commitment. Watch for this trap and redirect back toward genuine understanding.
When to use: Coach negotiators who receive 'You're right' responses. Help them recognize this as a red flag that the counterpart isn't truly bought in, and teach them to circle back with questions or summaries to get to 'That's right.'
communicationdifficult_peopleemotionsleverage
Coaching Move Use Labeling to Access Emotions and Motivations
Give the other party's feelings a name and express understanding. Example: 'It all seems so tragically unfair, I can see why you sound so angry.' This validation of emotions builds rapport and trust, making the counterpart more willing to engage. Labeling requires genuine observation of how the other person is feeling and reflecting it back with empathy.
When to use: Use when you sense the counterpart has emotional stakes in their position or when you're meeting resistance based on feelings rather than pure logic.
emotionsrelationshipcommunication
Coaching Move Lead with a Label to Shift Perspective
Open with an observation of the other party's feelings or mindset to create openness before negotiating a different direction. Example: 'You hate him, don't you?' This invitation to discuss emotions can unlock their perspective. Once they acknowledge their emotional state, they often gain control of it and become more flexible and collaborative.
When to use: Use when you sense the counterpart's emotional attachment to a position or when you need to negotiate with your own team member who has a strong emotional reaction to your strategy.
emotionsrelationshipdifficult_peoplecommunication
Coaching Move Reposition with the Counterpart's Own Words
Rather than arguing directly against the counterpart's position, reflect their logic and concerns back to them in a summary format. This creates distance from their original stance and allows them to evaluate it objectively. When they hear their own worldview articulated clearly, they often shift perspective naturally without feeling confronted.
When to use: Use when direct argument has failed and you need to reset a negotiation. Especially effective when the counterpart has been rigid on an issue for an extended period.
communicationleverageemotions
Example Schilling Hostage Negotiation Case Study
The FBI negotiated with Abu Sabaya for the release of kidnapped CIA-adjacent hostage Jeffrey Schilling, who had a $10 million price tag. Sabaya refused to move from his 'war damages' demand for months, citing 500 years of Islamic oppression. Using the active listening arsenal and a comprehensive summary of his grievances, negotiator Benjie got Sabaya to say 'That's right.' Immediately after, the demand disappeared entirely and Sabaya stopped demanding money. Sabaya later revealed he had planned to hurt Schilling but didn't. The summary created a realization point where Sabaya felt understood, breaking the deadlock.
When to use: Reference when coaching negotiators on high-stakes or emotional situations where direct pressure fails. Illustrates the power of genuine understanding over argument.
communicationleverageemotionsdifficult_people
Example Brandon Football Coaching Scenario
Chris Voss's son Brandon couldn't stop aggressively confronting opposing blockers even though his linebacker coach and Voss kept explaining it kept him from the ball. Brandon repeatedly said 'You're right' but didn't change. Voss shifted to labeling: 'You seem to think it's unmanly to dodge a block. You think it's cowardly to get out of someone's way.' Brandon responded 'That's right'—and immediately changed his behavior. He embraced the reality of what was holding him back and became an exceptional linebacker. This shows the power of emotional acknowledgment over logical argument.
When to use: Reference when coaching parents, coaches, managers, or anyone trying to influence behavior change in someone close to them. Shows the limits of logical reasoning when emotions are involved.
emotionsrelationshipcommunicationdifficult_people
Example Pharmaceutical Sales Breakthrough
A pharmaceutical sales rep was being dismissed by a major doctor who wouldn't listen to product benefits. She shifted tactics by summarizing his passion for tailoring treatments to individual patients and treating an overlooked epidemic. The doctor said 'That's right' and opened up, revealing challenges in his practice. She then summarized his challenges, he confirmed 'That's right,' and only then did she explain how her product specifically addressed his stated challenges. The doctor gave her a trial order. The breakthrough came from understanding his true motivation (patient care), not from pushing product features.
When to use: Reference when coaching sales professionals, business development, or anyone in client-facing roles who needs to build trust before pitching solutions.
information_gatheringrelationshipcommunicationleverage
Example Korean HR Career Negotiation
A Korean MBA graduate needed his ex-boss's approval to transfer from the semiconductor division to consumer products. The ex-boss initially rejected the idea. The student asked questions ('Is there any reason you want me to stay?' 'What made you decide that?') and discovered the real motivation: the boss needed a headquarters ally to communicate between divisions. Once the student summarized this insight—'So as long as I'm in headquarters and can help you communicate with top managers'—the ex-boss said 'That's right' and revealed everything. Understanding the true motivation opened the door. This shows how asking questions and summarizing uncovers what people really want beneath surface positions.
When to use: Reference when coaching on career negotiations, hierarchical power dynamics, or situations where the stated position masks the real underlying need.

Framework Understanding Counterpart Anchors and Reasoning
Before negotiating, work backward to understand how your counterpart arrived at their position. What data, comparables, or reasoning did they use to set their anchor? In the Schilling case, Sabaya anchored at $10 million based on: (1) a $5 million US bounty for undesirable terrorists, so more for a citizen; and (2) a $20 million precedent ransom for Western European captives. Understanding the anchor's logic helps you later reposition using that same logic in your favor.
When to use: Use in preparation phase when researching the counterpart. Helps explain their position rationally rather than assuming irrationality, which enables more effective repositioning.

Coaching Move Use Silence Strategically for Emphasis and Emotional Drainage
Effective pauses—strategic silence—are a powerful active listening tool. Silence encourages the other party to keep talking, which helps drain emotions from the dialogue over time. It also gives them space to reflect and adds weight to your summaries or labels. Extended silence after a key point can create discomfort that motivates movement.
When to use: Use when the counterpart is emotionally charged or when you've made a powerful summary and want to let it sink in. Particularly effective after labeling or mirroring.
communicationemotionsinformation_gathering
Coaching Move Mirror to Encourage Further Disclosure
When the counterpart makes a statement, repeat it back verbatim (or nearly so) to encourage them to continue talking and elaborating. Mirroring shows you're paying attention and prompts deeper disclosure without the resistance they might feel to direct questions. It's less confrontational than paraphrasing or labeling.
When to use: Use early in active listening when you want the counterpart to open up and talk more about their position, without yet showing your own understanding or interpretation.

Coaching Move Paraphrase to Demonstrate True Understanding
Repeat what the counterpart has said back to them in your own words. Paraphrasing powerfully demonstrates that you genuinely understand their position and aren't just parroting. It's a step toward full summary and 'That's right.' Paraphrasing without labeling is useful when you want to confirm factual understanding before acknowledging emotions.
When to use: Use after you've listened extensively and want to show understanding before moving to labeling or full summary. Also useful as a check—if your paraphrase is wrong, they'll correct you.

Ch 6. Bend Their Reality

49 items
How to use cognitive biases ethically: anchoring (set an extreme first offer to shift their frame), loss aversion (frame outcomes in terms of what they'll lose, not gain), and deadline pressure (deadlines are almost always flexible — the other side's deadline matters more than yours). Also covers when and how to use precise, non-round numbers ($37,263 instead of $37,000) to imply research and authority.

Framework Bend Their Reality Framework
Negotiation success depends on understanding the subterranean world of unspoken needs, hidden motivations, and irrational blind spots. Once you understand these deeper variables, you can leverage them to shift your counterpart's perception of what they need and deserve, conforming their reality to your objectives rather than capitulating to their initial demands.
When to use: When Ali needs to help negotiators move beyond surface-level positions to understand deeper motivations and psychological factors.

Coaching Move Never Split the Difference
Avoid the temptation to compromise by splitting the difference between positions. Compromise often produces the worst possible outcome and is driven by fear and desire to avoid pain rather than by actual goals. Instead, embrace creative problem-solving that risks confusion and conflict, as great deals emerge from addressing hard truths rather than false equivalence.
When to use: When a negotiator proposes meeting halfway or splitting the difference between offers, to redirect them toward creative solutions.

Example Mismatched Shoes Compromise Analogy
A husband and wife disagree about shoe color: she wants black, he wants brown. Compromising, he wears one black and one brown shoe—the worst outcome. Either all black or all brown would be superior to the compromise. This illustrates how splitting the difference creates an outcome worse than either original position.
When to use: When illustrating why compromise fails and creative solutions succeed, use this relatable example.

Coaching Move Understand Deadline Psychology
Deadlines create artificial pressure by triggering fear of future loss. Most deadlines are arbitrary, flexible, and rarely have real consequences. Recognizing this as psychological pressure rather than absolute constraint allows negotiators to resist rushing into bad deals and use time as an ally by maintaining patience.
When to use: When a negotiator expresses urgency due to a deadline or feels pressured to conclude quickly.

The closer they approach their deadline, the more specific and desperate their threats become.

When you reveal your cutoff date, you reduce impasse probability and encourage the other side to engage in real deal-making faster. The other side cannot exploit a deadline they don't know about because they'll hold out indefinitely thinking they have time.

Framework Threat Specificity Indicates Deadline Proximity
Evaluate threat credibility by measuring specificity across four dimensions: What? Who? When? How? Vague threats with ambiguities indicate early stage pressure; highly specific threats with all four dimensions addressed indicate proximity to real consequences and actual deadlines. Use increasing specificity as a signal to intensify or modify your strategy.
When to use: When analyzing the seriousness and timing of threats or demands in a negotiation.

Coaching Move Recognize Emotion Governs Decision-Making

Even irrational emotional choices (like rejecting free money) outweigh logical calculations. Accept that counterparts are emotional actors, not purely rational ones.

Framework The Ultimatum Game Framework
In the Ultimatum Game, a proposer divides money with an accepter; if accepter refuses, both get nothing. Most people make irrational emotional decisions: proposers rarely offer the logically optimal $1, and accepters reject insulting low offers despite getting $0. This demonstrates that fairness perception overrides rational self-interest in decision-making.
When to use: When illustrating how emotion and fairness perception override rational economic thinking.
emotionsleveragepower_dynamics
Coaching Move Never Assume Others Think Like You
Projecting your own reasoning onto counterparts is not empathy; it's a critical error. Each party uses different emotional logic to reach decisions. Assuming the other side reasons identically leads to miscalibrated offers and misread motivations. True empathy requires understanding their unique perspective, not assuming they share yours.
When to use: When a negotiator reports surprise at counterpart reactions or admits to making assumptions about counterpart thinking.
emotionscommunicationrelationshipleverage
Framework Fairness Perception Framework
The most powerful word in negotiation is 'Fair.' Humans are hardwired to react emotionally to fairness, with neural activity reflecting perceived unfairness. People comply with agreements when treated fairly and retaliate when feeling disrespected. Even irrational rejection of money (Ultimatum Game) and major economic decisions are driven by fairness perception rather than logic.
When to use: When explaining why fairness language and perception matters more than rational economic value in driving agreement.

Framework Distinguish Real vs. Imaginary Consequences
Deadlines create anxiety through perceived future loss consequences. In practice, across hundreds of business negotiations, virtually no missed deadlines produce actual negative consequences. Deadlines are almost always arbitrary and flexible. Understanding that consequences are typically imaginary rather than real allows negotiators to resist reactive decision-making.

Framework Compromise Driven by Fear and Safety

Framework Prospect Theory for negotiation
Prospect Theory describes how people choose between options involving risk. The Certainty Effect shows people prefer sure things over probabilities, even better ones. Loss Aversion shows people take greater risks to avoid losses than to achieve equal gains. Understanding these patterns allows negotiators to influence counterpart behavior predictably.
When to use: When Ali needs to explain why counterparts make seemingly irrational decisions or how to leverage their psychological vulnerabilities.

Framework Anchor and adjustment effect
People unconsciously adjust their estimates from initial reference points. When presented with extreme anchors, we tend to make adjustments toward reasonableness from that extreme. This is why high first offers work—they shift the entire negotiation range higher, even though counterparts 'adjust' down from the extreme.
When to use: When Ali is explaining to users why high opening anchors work or why they need to resist extreme first offers.

Ch 7. Create the Illusion of Control

23 items
Introduces calibrated questions — open-ended 'How' and 'What' questions that make the counterpart feel in control while actually directing the conversation. The template: "How am I supposed to do that?" This forces the other side to solve your problem for you. Calibrated questions eliminate 'I' and 'me' to remove ego, and avoid 'Why' which triggers defensiveness.
Coaching Move × 8 Framework × 4 Example × 4 Quote × 7
Coaching Move Calibrated Open-Ended Questions
Transform aggressive demands into open-ended questions that invite problem-solving rather than confrontation. Instead of saying "You can't leave," ask "What do you hope to achieve by going?" These questions remove hostility, acknowledge the other side, and nudge them toward your solution without sounding pushy. They work because they're subject to interpretation and offer no target for attack, forcing the counterpart to pause and think.
When to use: When you need to introduce ideas or requests without triggering defensive reactions, especially when moving away from confrontational dynamics or seeking information.
communicationpower_dynamicsinformation_gathering
Coaching Move Create Illusion of Control
The secret to gaining upper hand in negotiation is giving the other side the illusion of control. Ask questions that frame your desired outcome as their idea, so they volunteer to do what you want. This suspends their unbelief and transforms the dynamic from confrontational to collaborative problem-solving.
When to use: When you want to move a counterpart toward your position without directly imposing your view, to increase buy-in and reduce resistance.
power_dynamicscommunicationrelationship
Coaching Move Avoid Triggering Reciprocity
Don't ask for information that triggers the human reciprocity gene, where giving something obligates the receiver to give back. Closed-ended proof-of-life questions ("What was the teddy bear's name?") require minimal effort and immediately trigger reciprocity debt. Instead, use calibrated questions that lead counterparts to volunteer information, creating no obligation on your part.
When to use: When you want to extract concessions or information without incurring debt or triggering defensive reciprocal demands.
concessionsinformation_gatheringleverage
Coaching Move Ask for Help with 'How' Questions
Use 'how' questions to engage your counterpart's problem-solving instinct. 'How am I supposed to do that?' is one of the most powerful calibrated questions because 'how' engages by asking for help. It's natural, non-accusatory, and forces the counterpart to think about solving the problem rather than defending their position.
When to use: When you need to raise an objection or problem without sounding threatening or accusatory, especially around price negotiations or unmet obligations.
communicationleverageconcessions
Coaching Move Avoid Hard Confrontational Openers
Don't start negotiations with statements or closed-ended demands that position you as adversarial. Instead of saying "You're screwing me out of money and it has to stop," use calibrated questions that invite collaborative problem-solving. Hard confrontation triggers defensive unbelief and creates paralyzed showdowns.
When to use: At the opening of any negotiation where you want to establish a problem-solving rather than adversarial tone.
openingcommunicationrelationship
Coaching Move Suspend Unbelief Through Questions
Unbelief is active resistance to what the other side is saying—complete rejection. To suspend it, don't directly tell them what to believe; instead, ask calibrated questions that lead them to your point of view on the back of their own energy. You're not trying to get them believing what you say; you're just trying to stop them from disbelieving.
When to use: When facing strong initial resistance or ideological opposition, to gradually shift their perspective without direct confrontation.
communicationpower_dynamicsdifficult_people
Coaching Move Use Softening Language in Questions
Soften calibrated questions with phrases like 'perhaps,' 'maybe,' 'I think,' and 'it seems.' These words reduce the aggression and perceived threat of your question, making it subject to interpretation rather than a rigid demand. They allow you to introduce ideas without sounding overbearing or pushy.
When to use: When phrasing calibrated questions to ensure they feel collaborative and open rather than accusatory or demanding.
communicationrelationship
Coaching Move Design Questions With Directional Intent
Calibrated questions are not random requests for comment—they must be designed with a specific direction in mind. Figure out where you want the conversation to go, then design questions that ease the conversation in that direction while letting the other person think it's their choice. This requires careful calibration like adjusting a gun sight or scale.
When to use: During preparation and throughout negotiation to maintain strategic direction while preserving the counterpart's sense of agency.
preparationcommunicationstrategy
Framework Negotiation as Coaxing, Not Overcoming
Shift mental model from viewing negotiation as a wrestling match (exhaust opponent, never back down) to viewing it as coaxing and co-opting. Successful negotiation gets your counterpart to do the work for you and suggest your solution themselves. The goal is to define the conversation while giving them the illusion of control—this is fundamentally different from the old 'verbal flexing' approach where both sides try to impose their worldview.
When to use: When entering any negotiation to establish the right foundational mindset and avoid reversion to adversarial, positional tactics.
communicationpower_dynamicsrelationship
Framework Communication vs. Verbal Flexing
True communication is different from verbal flexing. Verbal flexing is when both sides want the other to see it their way, creating showdowns. Real communication is dialogue where you're jointly problem-solving. Replace the tit-for-tat mentality (if they give us something, we owe them) with a model where you extract information and concessions without triggering reciprocity obligations.
When to use: When diagnosing why negotiations are stuck or adversarial, to identify whether you're trapped in verbal flexing rather than genuine problem-solving.
communicationrelationshippower_dynamics
Framework Account for Teams on Both Sides
There is always a team on the other side. If your negotiation efforts don't reach past your immediate counterpart into the team behind them, you have a 'hope'-based deal, and hope is not a strategy. Changes in negotiators by the other side typically signal a harder line is coming. You must understand and account for dynamics within their team structure.
When to use: During preparation and when changes occur in who you're negotiating with, to understand power dynamics and potential obstacles hidden behind the primary contact.
preparationteam_negotiationinformation_gathering
Framework Information Gathering as Core Negotiation Purpose
All negotiation, done well, should be an information-gathering process that vests your counterpart in an outcome that serves you. Don't ask for something and immediately create reciprocity debt. Instead, design conversations where counterparts provide information, make concessions, and feel like they've chosen to do so because it solves their problem.
When to use: When structuring questions and conversation flow to ensure you're building information advantage while maintaining leverage.
information_gatheringleveragecommunication
Example Pittsburgh Drug Dealer Proof of Life
An untrained drug dealer, instead of asking a sophisticated proof-of-life question coached by FBI, simply asked 'Hey, dog, how do I know she's all right?' The kidnapper went silent, then voluntarily put the girlfriend on the phone. This unsophisticated open-ended 'how' question succeeded where coached closed-ended questions would have triggered reciprocity and confrontation. The kidnapper thought putting the hostage on the phone was his idea.
When to use: When demonstrating the power of natural, calibrated questions over formulaic approaches; when coaching someone nervous about how to ask for something without sounding accusatory.
communicationpower_dynamicsinformation_gathering
Example Senior Doctor Suspends Patient Unbelief
A patient ripped out his IV and was leaving because his biopsy results were delayed. A senior physician calmly offered water, acknowledged the patient's frustration, and asked a calibrated question: 'What do you feel is so important about leaving?' When the patient said he had errands, the doctor offered to connect him with services to handle them. The patient voluntarily stayed. The doctor transformed a showdown into collaborative problem-solving by giving the patient illusion of control.
When to use: When illustrating how calibrated questions work in non-hostage contexts (medical, customer service) to suspend unbelief and resolve conflicts.
communicationpower_dynamicsrelationshipdifficult_people
Example PR Firm 'How Am I Supposed to Do That' Success
A small PR firm was owed increasing money by a large client who kept promising repeat business. On consultant advice, the PR owner summarized the situation and asked 'How am I supposed to do that?' Despite her fear this would get her fired, the client responded 'You're right, you can't, and I apologize,' provided a new accounting contact, and promised payment within 48 hours. The calibrated question pushed the client to understand the problem and offer the solution without sounding accusatory.
When to use: When coaching on how to raise billing/payment issues or unmet obligations without triggering defensive reactions; when illustrating real-world business applications.

The FBI's tit-for-tat mentality made them afraid to ask for proof of life without triggering reciprocity debt. The whole operation was verbal flexing showdowns rather than communication. Eventually hostages were killed in friendly fire.

Ch 8. Guarantee Execution

50 items
'Yes' is nothing without 'How.' This chapter focuses on implementation: getting the other side to detail the specific steps they'll take. The '7-38-55 Rule': only 7% of a message is the words; 38% is tone of voice; 55% is body language. Watch for incongruence. Use the 'Rule of Three': get the other person to agree three different ways to ensure genuine commitment. Covers identifying deal-killers and behind-the-table stakeholders.

Framework Yes is Nothing Without How
An agreement alone is insufficient for successful negotiation. The true measure of success is implementation and execution. A signed contract or agreement has no value until it is actually implemented and produces results. The goal should be getting both consent AND execution.
When to use: When Ali helps a user understand why reaching agreement is only half the battle and they need to focus equally on ensuring the deal gets implemented.

Coaching Move Calibrated How Questions for Implementation
Use carefully crafted 'How' questions to force counterparts to think through implementation details. Questions like 'How will we know we're on track?' and 'How will we address things if we find we're off track?' push counterparts to articulate success criteria in their own words, increasing buy-in and follow-through.

Coaching Move Use How Questions to Say No Gracefully
Replace direct refusals with 'How' questions like 'How am I supposed to do that?' to elegantly deny demands without using the word 'No.' This approach, called 'forced empathy,' invites collaboration and makes the other side consider your perspective. Tone of voice is critical—deliver as a request for assistance, not an accusation.

Coaching Move Distinguish True Buy-In from Fake Agreement

Framework The Importance of That's Right
Summarize your counterpart's answers to calibrated questions until they respond with 'That's right.' This phrase indicates genuine buy-in and agreement, whereas 'You're right' is often dismissive. Getting 'That's right' ensures they truly own the solution and will be motivated to implement it.

Framework Behind-the-Table Players (Level II Analysis)
In any negotiation, identify and consider 'behind-the-table' or 'Level II' players—parties not directly at the negotiating table who can help implement agreements they like or block ones they don't. Coaching Move Use Repetitive Questions to Overcome Aggression
Ask a series of "What" and "How" questions repeatedly to overcome aggressive tactics from manipulative adversaries. This technique disarms difficult counterparts by keeping them engaged while subtly shifting their thinking toward your perspective. The repetition can lead them to make unexpected commitments without fully realizing what they've agreed to.

Framework The 7-38-55 Percent Rule
Only 7% of a message is based on words, while 38% comes from tone of voice and 55% from body language and facial expression. Body language and tone are more powerful assessment tools than words. When tone and body language don't align with the literal words being said, the speaker may be lying or unconvinced.
When to use: When assessing whether a counterpart is being truthful or genuinely committed to an agreement.
communicationemotionsleverage
Coaching Move Label Incongruence Between Words and Nonverbals
When you notice a mismatch between someone's words and their tone or body language, use a label to gently point out the incongruence. This builds trust and respect because it shows you're paying close attention and care about getting the agreement right. The counterpart will appreciate the recognition and be more likely to reveal the real issue.
When to use: When someone says "Yes" but their tone or body language suggests hesitation or doubt.
communicationemotionsrelationshipclosing
Framework The Rule of Three
Get the other party to agree to the same thing three times in the same conversation using different tactics. The first agreement is the initial commitment. The second can be a label or summary that elicits "That's right." The third can be a calibrated question about implementation. This makes it harder for them to lie or fake conviction and uncovers problems before they happen.
When to use: When you want to verify that a counterpart's commitment is genuine and not a counterfeit "Yes."
closingcommunicationverification
Coaching Move Vary Tactics to Avoid Sounding Repetitive
When applying the Rule of Three, vary your approach with each agreement request so you don't sound like a broken record or appear pushy. Use different methods: direct agreement, labeling/summarizing, calibrated questions, or rephrasing the same question in different ways. This maintains rapport while still drilling in the commitment.
When to use: When executing the Rule of Three to ensure the process feels natural and respectful rather than manipulative.
communicationrelationshipclosing
Framework The Pinocchio Effect
Liars typically use more words than truth-tellers, rely heavily on third-person pronouns (him, her, it, they) to distance themselves from the lie, and speak in complex sentences to win over suspicious listeners. The number of words grows with the lie because liars are more worried about being believed and overcompensate in their persuasion efforts.
When to use: When assessing whether a counterpart is being truthful based on their speech patterns and word choices.
communicationleverageemotions
Coaching Move Monitor Pronoun Usage to Assess Power and Honesty
Track whether a counterpart uses first-person pronouns (I, me, my) versus avoiding them. Those who frequently use first-person pronouns are less important in the decision chain. Those who avoid first-person pronouns and use "we," "they," and "them" are likely more powerful and are deferring to people away from the table. Also watch for liars who distance themselves from statements using third-person pronouns.
When to use: When trying to identify who the real decision-maker is or when assessing the honesty of a counterpart.
power_dynamicsinformation_gatheringcommunication
Coaching Move The Chris Discount - Use Your Own Name
Introduce yourself by your own name in a friendly, fun way rather than overusing the counterpart's name like a pushy salesman. Using your own name creates "forced empathy" and humanizes you, making the other side see you as a person rather than an adversary. This simple act can transform a hostile or transactional interaction into a more collaborative one.
When to use: In any negotiation or sales situation to build rapport and increase the likelihood of getting better terms or a favorable outcome.

Coaching Move Say "No" Four Ways Before Using the Word
Express "No" indirectly four times before actually saying the word "No." First: "How am I supposed to do that?" (delivered deferentially). Second: "Your offer is very generous, I'm sorry, that just doesn't work for me." Third: "I'm sorry but I'm afraid I just can't do that." Fourth: "I'm sorry, no." This approach avoids shutting down the counterpart's pride and often leads them to bid against themselves.
When to use: When you need to reject an offer but want to keep the negotiation open and encourage the counterpart to make a better offer.
closingcommunicationleverageconcessions
Coaching Move "How am I supposed to do that?" - Deferential No
Deliver this phrase in a way that sounds like a request for help rather than a rejection. It invites the other side to participate in your dilemma and solve it with a better offer. This is the gentlest form of saying "No" and triggers the counterpart's problem-solving instinct.
When to use: As the first indirect "No" when rejecting an offer or proposal.
closingcommunicationleverage
Coaching Move Use "Generous" to Nurture Better Offers
When declining an offer, say something like "Your offer is very generous, I'm sorry, that just doesn't work for me." The word "generous" works double duty: it acknowledges their effort positively and subconsciously encourages them to live up to being truly generous by improving their offer. This builds empathy while still rejecting.
When to use: When making the second indirect "No" to encourage the counterpart toward a better offer.
closingcommunicationrelationshipleverage
Coaching Move Express Inability Rather Than Unwillingness
Use language like "I'm afraid I just can't do that" which expresses an inability to perform rather than unwillingness to perform. This triggers the other side's empathy toward you because inability is less confrontational than unwillingness, and people are naturally inclined to help those facing constraints.
When to use: When making the third indirect "No" to soften the rejection and appeal to the counterpart's empathy.
closingcommunicationemotionsleverage
Coaching Move Deliver "No" with Downward Inflection and Regard
If you must say the word "No" directly, deliver it with a downward inflection and a tone of regard rather than as an emphatic "NO!" This maintains the relationship and signals respect even while rejecting the offer definitively.
When to use: When all four indirect "No" methods have been exhausted and you must state "No" directly.
closingcommunicationrelationship
Framework Multi-Step No Strategy for Bidding Against Themselves
By saying "No" using gentle, indirect methods in sequence, counterparts often perceive your rejections as counterbids and respond by improving their offer. Each rejection should be carefully crafted without making an explicit counteroffer, using empathy-building language like apologies, acknowledgment of their effort, and explanation of constraints. This can lead them to bid progressively lower or better against themselves.
When to use: When negotiating with a counterpart who is motivated to make a deal and you want them to improve their offer without you having to push aggressively.
closingleveragecommunicationconcessions
Example Cannabis Business Buyout Using Multi-Step No
Joaquin and Bruno negotiated a share buyout where Bruno initially demanded €30,812. Using the multi-step "No" strategy, Joaquin sent four increasingly sympathetic rejections without counteroffers. Bruno's advisor progressively lowered the price from €30,812 to €28,346 to €25,000, eventually accepting €23,567. The key was using mirroring and open questions to uncover Bruno's financial desperation, then exploiting it through gentle rejections that made Bruno feel he was making concessions voluntarily.
When to use: As a real-world case study showing how the multi-step "No" strategy works when a counterpart is motivated and has limited alternatives.

Coaching Move Use Specific Numbers in Final Offers
When making a final counteroffer after rejecting multiple times, use highly specific numbers (e.g., €23,567 and €15,321.37 rather than €23,500 and €15,000). Specific numbers appear more carefully calculated and deliberate, suggesting you've truly exhausted your options and can't go further. This makes the offer seem immovable while paradoxically being more believable.

Ch 9. Bargain Hard

24 items
The Ackerman Bargaining System — Voss's tactical price negotiation model. Set your target, then offer 65%, 85%, 95%, and 100% in calculated increments. Use precise non-round numbers. Add a non-monetary item on the final offer to signal you're at your limit. Also covers identifying counterpart bargaining styles (Analyst, Accommodator, Assertive) and adapting your approach to each.
Coaching Move × 13 Framework × 2 Example × 2 Quote × 7
Coaching Move Rattle the Other Guy Gently
Open a haggle by gently rattling your counterpart with your first offer, delivered in the nicest way possible. This small disruption to their expectations creates an opening for negotiation. The key is threading the needle between assertiveness and friendliness—enough to shake their confidence in their initial position without triggering defensiveness or anger.
When to use: When beginning the bargaining phase after rapport has been established and you're ready to move from discussion to actual offer exchange.
openingbargainingpsychologypower_dynamics
Coaching Move Use Strategic Silence After Your Offer
After making an offer, use silence strategically. Don't fill the void with justifications or counter-arguments. Let your counterpart sit with discomfort and process your offer. Their silence doesn't mean rejection—often they're reconsidering their position. The longer they stay silent, the better your position.
When to use: Immediately after presenting your opening offer or counteroffer in bargaining, to allow the other party time to absorb and react without pressure.
bargainingpsychologycommunicationpower_dynamics
Coaching Move Apologize and Demur Rather Than Justify
When your offer is rejected, use phrases like 'I'm sorry, I just can't do that price' rather than launching into reasons why. Add genuine-sounding apologies and admissions of constraint ('This is so embarrassing') to soften the stance while remaining firm. This approach maintains dignity while signaling immovability.
When to use: When responding to a rejection of your offer during the bargaining phase, especially if you want to hold your position without escalating tension.
bargainingcommunicationemotionsconcessions
Coaching Move Recognize Non-Rejection as Advantage Signal
Any response that's not an outright rejection of your offer means you have the edge in negotiation. Even if the other party stands firm or goes silent, the fact they haven't walked away or flatly refused indicates they're still engaged and reconsidering. Use this as confidence that you can continue negotiating.
When to use: When interpreting counterpart responses during bargaining to assess whether you maintain negotiating leverage.
bargainingleveragepower_dynamicsinformation_gathering
Coaching Move Praise Offers While Still Refusing Them
Acknowledge the generosity or reasonableness of an offer while maintaining your position: 'Your offer is very generous and I'm grateful, but I still cannot do that price.' This preserves the relationship and keeps the door open for continued negotiation without giving ground.
When to use: When rejecting an offer during bargaining while wanting to maintain rapport and signal continued willingness to negotiate.
bargainingrelationshipcommunicationconcessions
Framework Three Negotiator Types Framework
Negotiators fall into three categories: Analysts (methodical, data-driven, time-independent, hate surprises), Accommodators (relationship-focused, communication-oriented, win-win oriented, poor at conflict), and Assertives (time-conscious, winning-focused, direct, aggressive, results-driven). Each type has distinct communication patterns, preparation styles, and interpretations of silence. Success requires identifying your counterpart's type and adapting your approach accordingly, not projecting your own style onto them.
When to use: At the beginning of a negotiation preparation phase to diagnose both your own style and your counterpart's style, then adjust tactics throughout the negotiation.
preparationpower_dynamicscommunicationdifficult_people
Coaching Move Identify Analyst Type and Adjust Tactics
Analysts are methodical, detail-oriented, emotionally reserved, hate surprises, and hypersensitive to reciprocity. To negotiate with them: use clear data to drive arguments, avoid ad-libbing, use data comparisons to disagree, warn of issues early, avoid surprises, let silence be thinking time (not anger), use labels but not immediate questions, and smile to encourage information sharing. Don't expect quick counterproposals; they need time to evaluate concessions as new data.
When to use: When you've identified your counterpart as an Analyst type during the preparation or opening phase.
preparationinformation_gatheringcommunicationpower_dynamics
Coaching Move Identify Accommodator Type and Adjust Tactics
Accommodators prioritize relationship-building, are sociable and friendly, rarely create conflict, often agree before they can deliver, and can build rapport without achieving outcomes. To negotiate with them: be sociable and friendly, use calibrated questions focused on implementation, recognize they may have committed to things they can't deliver, and push them gently toward action. If you're an Accommodator, don't sacrifice your objections just to keep peace.
When to use: When you've identified your counterpart as an Accommodator type, or when self-coaching if you recognize yourself as an Accommodator.
preparationrelationshipcommunicationpower_dynamics
Coaching Move Identify Assertive Type and Adjust Tactics
Assertives are time-focused, winning-focused, direct, aggressive communicators who want to be heard first before they can listen. They view business relationships as based on respect, not personal connection. To negotiate with them: focus first on letting them be heard, use mirrors and calibrated questions to make yourself more approachable, get a 'that's right' confirmation, and recognize they operate on 'give an inch/take a mile' reciprocity logic. If you're Assertive, intentionally soften your tone.
When to use: When you've identified your counterpart as an Assertive type, or when self-coaching if you recognize yourself as an Assertive.
preparationrelationshipcommunicationpower_dynamics
Coaching Move Interpret Silence According to Type
Different negotiator types interpret silence differently: for Analysts, silence means thinking time; for Accommodators, silence signals anger or discomfort; for Assertives, silence means you're done talking or want them to talk. Understanding your counterpart's type allows you to correctly interpret their silences. Assertives talking over an Analyst's thinking time annoys the Analyst; Accommodators get nervous when Analysts pause.
When to use: When your counterpart goes silent during negotiation and you need to interpret what it means and how to respond.
communicationpower_dynamicsdifficult_people
Framework The 'I Am Normal' Paradox Trap
Negotiators unconsciously assume the world looks to others as it looks to them—that their 'normal' is universal. With three negotiator types existing, there's a 66% chance your counterpart operates with a different 'normal.' This unconscious projection of your own style onto the other side is one of the most damaging assumptions in negotiation. Success requires opening yourself to the other person's difference.
When to use: During preparation and throughout negotiation as a meta-awareness tool to catch yourself projecting your style on your counterpart.
preparationpower_dynamicspsychologydifficult_people
Quote The Black Swan Rule vs. Golden Rule
"The Black Swan rule is don't treat others the way you want to be treated; treat them the way they need to be treated."
When to use: When coaching someone who is struggling with their negotiation approach and reverting to their natural style despite having a different counterpart type.
power_dynamicsrelationshipcommunication
Coaching Move Deflect Extreme Anchors with Strategic Deflection
When facing an extreme or ridiculous opening offer (anchor), don't respond with emotion or by immediately countering. Instead, deflect the punch by asking calibrated questions like 'How am I supposed to accept that?' or 'What are we trying to accomplish here?' These redirect the conversation and prevent you from being pulled into a compromise that splits the difference between a ridiculous offer and your realistic one.
When to use: When your counterpart leads with an extreme anchor that triggers emotional reaction, during the opening phase of bargaining.
anchoringbargainingcommunicationpower_dynamics
Coaching Move Pivot to Non-Monetary Terms Against Anchors
When feeling pulled into a haggling war over price via extreme anchoring, pivot to non-monetary issues. Say: 'Let's put price off to the side for a moment and talk about what would make this a good deal' or 'What else would you be able to offer to make that price work for me?' This detour breaks the anchor's power and opens space for creative problem-solving.
When to use: When an extreme price anchor threatens to derail negotiation or pull you into a bidding war, during the bargaining phase.
anchoringbargainingcreativitycommunication
Coaching Move Avoid Anchoring First by Referencing Third Parties
If forced to anchor first, don't name your own price. Instead, reference an external benchmark or comparable: 'Well, if you go to Harvard Business School, they charge $2,500 per student per day.' This allows you to establish a high anchor without it being your personal ask, making it feel more objective. It also buys you information about how they react to that reference point.
When to use: When the counterpart insists you anchor first and you want to avoid revealing your true range while still setting a high anchor.
anchoringbargaininginformation_gatheringleverage
Example Voss's Red Toyota 4Runner Negotiation
Voss wanted a specific red Toyota 4Runner priced at $36,000. He opened with $30,000 cash, delivered apologetically. The salesman rejected it. Voss used strategic silence, gentle apologies, and praise for the truck while refusing prices of $34,000 and $32,500. After multiple rounds where the salesman retreated to his manager, Voss finally got the truck for exactly $30,000. The key was maintaining his anchor despite the salesman's counters and using silence and demurral rather than justification.
When to use: When coaching someone on holding their position during multi-round bargaining or dealing with a counterpart who keeps coming back with small concessions.
bargaininganchoringconcessionspower_dynamics
Example Farouq and the Dean's Alumni Event Funding
Georgetown MBA student Farouq needed $600 from his dean for a Dubai alumni event. The dean opened with only $300. Rather than accepting or folding, Farouq: (1) acknowledged her limits while saying no, (2) dropped an extreme anchor of $1,000, (3) held firm through multiple punches—$500, $850 offers—using phrases like 'I understand your restrictions but...' and specific numbers like $775 and $737.50. The dean ultimately approved $750. Farouq's success came from not folding after the initial punch, pushing back strategically, and being specific about his needs.
When to use: When coaching someone facing an unexpectedly low opening offer and needing to recover negotiating position without damaging the relationship.
bargaininganchoringconcessionspower_dynamicsleverage
Coaching Move Punch Back: Use Strong Moves When Negotiation Stalls
When a negotiation is far from resolution and going nowhere, you need to shake things up with strong moves and aggression. Sometimes the situation calls for you to be the aggressor and assert yourself forcefully. This is different from the early bargaining phase; it's a tactical escalation when normal pressure hasn't moved the needle.
When to use: When negotiations have stalled, the counterpart is locked into a rigid position, and normal tactics (mirroring, labels, calibrated questions) have failed to create movement.
bargainingpower_dynamicsdifficult_peopleleverage
Quote Everybody Has a Plan Until They Get Punched
"Everybody has a plan until they get punched in the mouth." — Mike Tyson
When to use: When coaching someone preparing for negotiation and emphasizing the need to mentally prepare for extreme anchors and unexpected aggressive tactics from counterparts.
bargainingpreparationpsychologypower_dynamics
Quote Bargaining Induces More Anxiety Than Other Phases
"No part of a negotiation induces more anxiety and unfocused aggression than bargaining, which is why it's the part that is more often fumbled and mishandled than any other."
When to use: When coaching someone experiencing anxiety about the bargaining phase or explaining why people commonly make mistakes during price negotiations.
bargainingemotionspsychologycommunication
Quote Skilled Bargainers Read Psychological Currents
"Skilled bargainers see more than just opening offers, counteroffers, and closing moves. They see the psychological currents that run below the surface."
When to use: When encouraging someone to move beyond mechanical bargaining tactics and develop deeper psychological insight into negotiation dynamics.
bargainingpsychologypower_dynamicscommunication
Quote Assertiveness Not Required for Effective Bargaining
"A study of American lawyer-negotiators found that 65 percent of attorneys from two major U.S. cities used a cooperative style while only 24 percent were truly assertive. And when these lawyers were graded for effectiveness, more than 75 percent of the effective group came from the cooperative type; only 12 percent were Assertive."
When to use: When coaching a naturally cooperative or accommodating negotiator who believes they must become aggressive to be effective.
bargainingpower_dynamicspsychologycommunication
Quote Blunt Assertion Is Counterproductive
"Blunt assertion is actually counterproductive most of the time."
When to use: When coaching an aggressive negotiator who relies too heavily on direct pressure and isn't getting results, or when helping someone understand why aggressive opening tactics backfire.
bargainingpower_dynamicscommunicationdifficult_people
Quote To Be Great, Add to Strengths, Don't Replace
"To be good, you have to learn to be yourself at the bargaining table. To be great you have to add to your strengths, not replace them."
When to use: When coaching someone to develop their negotiating style authentically while still expanding their tactical range beyond their natural type.

Ch 10. Find the Black Swan

24 items
Black Swans are unknown unknowns — leverage-shifting pieces of information the other side has but hasn't revealed (and may not know they have). Every negotiation has 3-5 Black Swans. Finding them requires deep listening and face-to-face contact. Three types of leverage: positive (ability to give what they want), negative (ability to cause pain), and normative (using their own standards against them).
Coaching Move × 14 Framework × 2 Example × 2 Quote × 6
Framework Known Knowns vs. Unknown Unknowns
Negotiations contain three types of information: known knowns (things we know, like counterpart's name and offer), known unknowns (things we know exist but don't know specifics, like wild cards in poker), and unknown unknowns or Black Swans (game-changing information we've never imagined). Most negotiators rely too heavily on known knowns and miss the Black Swans that can shift dynamics entirely.
When to use: When coaching someone stuck in conventional thinking or relying only on prior experience and research.
information_gatheringpreparationpower_dynamics
Coaching Move Shift from Template-Based to Adaptive Thinking
Stop fitting new situations into old templates from past experiences. When information doesn't add up, your frame of reference is likely wrong. Retain a beginner's mind, remain flexible and adaptable to each unique situation, and never overvalue experience or undervalue the informational and emotional realities presented in the moment.
When to use: When a negotiator is making assumptions based on 'how things usually work' or trying to force a situation into familiar patterns.
preparationcommunicationemotionspower_dynamics
Coaching Move Embrace Intuitive and Nuanced Listening
Black Swan discovery requires opening established mental pathways and embracing more intuitive, nuanced ways of listening. Rather than following conventional questioning techniques designed to confirm known knowns, you must feel for the truth behind camouflage, note small pauses suggesting discomfort or lies, and open yourself to factual reality in front of you without imposing expectations.
When to use: When coaching someone stuck in data-gathering mode or following rote question checklists without truly hearing their counterpart.
information_gatheringcommunicationemotionslistening
Coaching Move Ask 'Why Are They Communicating This Now?'
Instead of focusing heavily on end objectives, ask yourself in each moment: 'Why are they communicating what they are communicating right now?' This shifts focus to the next step rather than the finish line. Like walking a tightrope, concentrating on each step keeps you from falling off; completing all steps leads to the objective.
When to use: When a negotiator is laser-focused on their goal and missing signals about what's actually happening in real-time.
information_gatheringcommunicationemotions
Coaching Move Recognize That Innocuous Information Can Be Black Swans
Black Swans often appear completely innocuous and may not seem proprietary or closely guarded. Your counterpart always possesses pieces of information whose value they do not understand. Don't dismiss seemingly small or obvious details; they may be game-changing when properly interpreted.
When to use: When coaching someone who dismisses seemingly obvious or casual remarks from their counterpart.
information_gatheringleveragepower_dynamics
Framework Three Types of Leverage
Leverage exists in three forms: Positive (your ability to provide or withhold what counterpart wants), Negative (your ability to inflict loss or damage), and Normative (using counterpart's own rules and moral framework against inconsistencies). Black Swans are leverage multipliers. Understanding which type applies in each situation determines your approach.
When to use: When teaching someone how to identify and build leverage, or when analyzing what type of advantage they currently hold.
leveragepower_dynamicsalternatives
Coaching Move Understand Leverage as Emotional, Not Actual
Leverage is primarily an emotional concept. What matters is not what leverage actually exists but what leverage your counterpart thinks you have. Leverage can be manufactured whether it objectively exists or not. If they're talking to you, you have leverage—your job is to make them feel it.
When to use: When a negotiator feels they have weak objective leverage or is discouraged about their position.
leveragepower_dynamicsemotionspsychology
Coaching Move Positive Leverage: Control What They Want
When your counterpart reveals desire ('I want to buy your X'), you have positive leverage. You control what they want. Experienced negotiators delay making offers to preserve this leverage. Once you have positive leverage, identify other things they want and offer help in exchange for concessions—create reciprocal desire rather than one-sided wanting.
When to use: When the counterpart has expressed a clear want or desire for your product, service, or asset.
leveragepositive_leverageconcessionscreativity
Coaching Move Negative Leverage: Identify What They Fear Losing
Discover what is important to your counterpart—their audience, status symbols, and worries. Negative leverage comes from understanding what they're afraid to lose (loss aversion is more powerful than potential gains). Use a subtle labeling technique ('It seems like you strongly value...') rather than direct threats, which can trigger loss of autonomy and shut down negotiation.
When to use: When you need to motivate counterpart through fear of loss, but want to preserve the relationship and negotiation.
leveragenegative_leverageemotionspower_dynamics
Coaching Move Avoid Direct Threats; Use Subtle Labeling Instead
Direct threats are like nuclear bombs with toxic residue that's hard to clean up. Instead of making threats, use labeling to make negative consequences clear without attacking or removing counterpart's autonomy. Frame statements like 'It seems like you don't care what position you are leaving me in' to open dialogue rather than trigger defensive shutdown.
When to use: When you're tempted to use threats or when you need to raise stakes without escalating tension dangerously.
leveragenegative_leveragerelationshipethics
Coaching Move Normative Leverage: Reflect Their Own Values Back
Discover what your counterpart believes about standards, multiples, methods, and best practices. Show inconsistencies between their stated beliefs and actions—no one likes appearing hypocratic. Use their own language and values to frame your position. Ask what they believe and listen openly to understand their moral framework.
When to use: When you understand your counterpart's stated values, principles, or professional standards and need to align them with your proposal.
leveragenormative_leveragecommunicationcreativity
Coaching Move Distinguish Leverage from Power
Power and leverage are different. Someone with great power (like Donald Trump) has less leverage if they need something the other side controls. Leverage is about who has more to lose if negotiations collapse. Be aware of which party feels they have more to lose at any moment—that party has less leverage. Your goal is to make counterpart feel they have something to lose.
When to use: When coaching someone who confuses their objective power or status with their actual negotiating leverage.
leveragepower_dynamicspsychology
Coaching Move Understand the Hidden Negotiation Space
There is the visible negotiation and a hidden negotiation space beneath the surface where Black Swans dwell. Access this space by understanding your counterpart's worldview, their reason for being, their 'religion' (not necessarily literal faith). Digging into their worldview moves beyond the table and into their emotional and life context, which is where influence is built.
When to use: When you need to go deeper than surface-level discussion to understand what truly drives your counterpart.
information_gatheringemotionsrelationshipcommunication
Coaching Move Know Your Counterpart's Religion
Understand your counterpart's fundamental belief system, values, and worldview—their 'religion.' This is how you unearth who they really are rather than logically arguing them into submission. Once you understand their worldview, you can build influence by speaking to what matters to them and creating options that resonate with their values.
When to use: When you need to move beyond transactional negotiation to create genuine agreement rooted in shared values.
information_gatheringrelationshipemotionscommunication
Coaching Move Listen for Articulated Rules and Standards
Listen for when your counterpart reveals their personal rules, professional standards, or moral codes ('As a veteran, I learned...' or 'Our company always...'). These articulated rules provide normative leverage you can hold them to. They also reveal how your counterpart sees themselves and what guides their decision-making.
When to use: When your counterpart mentions their profession, background, values, or how they typically operate.
information_gatheringleveragenormative_leveragecommunication
Coaching Move Determine If They Want to Live (Survive the Deal)
In any high-stakes negotiation, determine whether your counterpart's vision of the future involves surviving/winning or whether they're committed to a destructive course. Look for signs they're willing to withdraw, back down, or find alternatives—these indicate they want a future. This changes how you approach leverage and options.
When to use: In high-stakes or emotional negotiations where counterpart may be operating from desperation or self-destruction.
information_gatheringpower_dynamicsemotionsleverage
Example William Griffin Bank Hostage Case (June 1981)
FBI negotiators assumed William Griffin wanted money, respect, and a helicopter because that's what hostage-takers 'always' wanted. But they missed multiple Black Swans: Griffin had already killed people without making monetary demands, refused to communicate (hostage-takers always talk), and left a note saying 'after the police take my life.' These clues indicated Griffin wanted suicide-by-cop, not negotiation. By the 3 p.m. deadline, Griffin killed hostage Margaret Moore—the first hostage killed on deadline in U.S. history. The lesson: when information doesn't fit your template, break free from expectations.
When to use: When illustrating how reliance on 'known knowns' blinds negotiators, or when showing the danger of ignoring contradictory signals.
preparationinformation_gatheringpower_dynamicsdifficult_people
Example Dwight Watson Tractor Protest (March 2003)
A North Carolina tobacco farmer drove a tractor with bombs to Washington D.C. to protest farming policies. Through careful listening, negotiators discovered: (1) Watson's positive leverage—he wanted attention for his cause; (2) his normative leverage—as a veteran, he had military codes about withdrawing with honor if reinforcements didn't arrive in three days; (3) his desire to live despite threats. Using his own 82nd Airborne training against him, negotiators created a face-saving three-day withdrawal window that aligned with his values and allowed him to surrender with honor.
When to use: When illustrating how understanding counterpart's worldview, rules, and values creates normative leverage, or when showing the importance of listening to uncover what drives them.
information_gatheringleveragenormative_leveragerelationshipemotions
Quote Black Swan Definition
'Black Swans are just a metaphor, of course. Think of Pearl Harbor, the rise of the Internet, 9/11, and the recent banking crisis. None of the events above was predicted—yet on reflection, the markers were all there. It's just that people weren't paying attention.'
When to use: When explaining why seemingly unforeseeable information was actually detectable if you look carefully.
information_gatheringpower_dynamics
Quote Leverage Always Exists
'There's always leverage: as an essentially emotional concept, it can be manufactured whether it exists or not. If they're talking to you, you have leverage.'
When to use: When encouraging someone who feels they have no leverage, or when explaining that leverage is psychological not just objective.
leveragepower_dynamicsemotions
Quote The Tightrope Principle
'Negotiation is more like walking on a tightrope than competing against an opponent. Focusing so much on the end objective will only distract you from the next step, and that can cause you to fall off the rope. Concentrate on the next step because the rope will lead you to the end as long as all the steps are completed.'
When to use: When coaching someone who is too focused on their ultimate goal and missing important signals or steps in the moment.
communicationemotionspreparation
Quote On Overreliance on Experience
'We must let what we know—our known knowns—guide us but not blind us to what we do not know; we must remain flexible and adaptable to any situation; we must always retain a beginner's mind; and we must never overvalue our experience or undervalue the informational and emotional realities served up moment by moment.'
When to use: When a negotiator is relying too heavily on how similar situations were handled in the past.
preparationcommunicationpower_dynamics
Quote On Understanding Counterpart's Worldview
'In any negotiation, but especially in a tense one like this, it's not how well you speak but how well you listen that determines your success. Understanding the 'other' is a precondition to be able to speak persuasively and develop options that resonate for them.'
When to use: When emphasizing that listening and understanding are more important than talking or arguing, especially in difficult situations.
communicationrelationshipemotionsinformation_gathering
Quote On Implicit Information Value
'Most people expect that Black Swans are highly proprietary or closely guarded information, when in fact the information may seem completely innocuous. Either side may be completely oblivious to its importance. Your counterpart always has pieces of information whose value they do not understand.'
When to use: When encouraging someone to take seriously the 'small talk' or casual remarks from their counterpart rather than dismissing them.
information_gatheringleveragecommunication

Appendix: Prepare a Negotiation One Sheet

23 items
Voss's practical preparation tool — a single-page framework to fill out before any negotiation. Sections: your goal (best/worst outcomes), a summary to trigger 'that's right,' labels to perform, calibrated questions to ask, non-cash items to offer. This is the operational distillation of every technique in the book.
Coaching Move × 10 Framework × 7 Example × 1 Quote × 5
Framework Negotiation One Sheet Structure
A five-section preparation document that organizes key negotiation tools and strategy before entering a negotiation. The five sections are: Goal, Summary, Labels/Accusation Audit, Calibrated Questions, and Noncash Offers. This framework prevents over-scripting while ensuring systematic preparation and readiness for psychological investigation of the other party.
When to use: When a user is preparing for an upcoming negotiation and needs a structured approach to organize their preparation.
preparationopeningcommunication
Coaching Move Set High-End Aspirational Goal Only
Replace BATNA focus with a single, specific, optimistic but realistic high-end goal. Write it down, discuss it with a colleague to commit to it, and carry it into the negotiation. This primes your psychological powers to perceive any term falling short as a loss, triggering loss-aversion motivation. Research shows people who set specific, challenging goals get better deals than those who don't.
When to use: When a user is defining their negotiation target or worried about settling too low.
preparationanchoringpower_dynamics
Coaching Move Think Best and Worst, Write Only Best
During preparation, mentally map both best-case and worst-case scenarios to feel secure and ready for anything. However, only write down the optimistic best-case goal on your one sheet. This gives you psychological structure without anchoring yourself to a ceiling—keeping flexibility and openness to outcomes even better than you imagined.
When to use: When a user is struggling with goal-setting anxiety or fear of asking too high.
preparationanchoringalternatives
Quote Pressure Reveals True Preparation
"When the pressure is on, you don't rise to the occasion—you fall to your highest level of preparation." This emphasizes why thorough one-sheet preparation is critical; you will instinctively default to what you've prepared under stress, not improvise brilliantly.
When to use: When a user is tempted to skip preparation or underestimates how stress will affect their negotiation performance.
preparationemotions
Framework BATNA vs. Aspirational Goal Mindset
BATNA (Best Alternative To Negotiated Agreement) is the industry standard but is psychologically limiting because humans fixate on the most salient focal point in complex situations. Obsessing over BATNA makes it your mental target, setting an upper limit on what you ask for. Instead, focus your preparation on a high aspirational goal to prime loss-aversion psychology and expand your perceived possibilities.
When to use: When a user is over-relying on BATNA thinking or feels trapped by their walk-away alternative.
preparationpower_dynamicsalternatives
Quote People Who Expect More Get More
"People who expect more (and articulate it) get more." This captures the core insight that goal-setting research confirms: explicit high expectations shape negotiation outcomes through psychological priming and signal-sending to the other party.
When to use: When a user lacks confidence in asking for their aspirational goal or fears being perceived as unreasonable.
preparationpower_dynamicsanchoring
Coaching Move Write Summary to Achieve 'That's Right'
Prepare a concise two-sentence summary of known facts leading to the negotiation. Test it with your counterpart and refine until they respond with 'That's right,' not just 'Yes.' This ensures you've achieved genuine agreement on baseline facts and framing, not mere surface acknowledgment. Getting to 'That's right' means you've correctly validated their perspective.
When to use: When a user is preparing their opening positioning or wants to establish psychological agreement with the other party.
preparationopeningcommunicationrelationship
Coaching Move Prepare Three to Five Accusation Audit Labels
Anticipate negative accusations or concerns the other party might raise—including unfair or ridiculous ones. Convert each into a label using fill-in-the-blank templates like 'It seems like you don't like ________' or 'It seems like _________ is valuable to you.' Pre-role-play these labels so you can deploy them smoothly to defuse tension and show empathy before accusations escalate.
When to use: When preparing for a difficult counterpart, heated negotiation, or when you anticipate specific objections.
preparationemotionsdifficult_peoplecommunication
Framework Universal Label Templates
Five fill-in-the-blank label structures work across nearly all negotiations: 'It seems like _________ is valuable to you'; 'It seems like you don't like _________'; 'It seems like you value __________'; 'It seems like _________ makes it easier'; 'It seems like you're reluctant to _________.' These templates allow rapid deployment of accusation audit labels without requiring custom phrasing.
When to use: When a user needs quick templates to prepare their labels section or needs examples of label formats.
preparationcommunicationemotions
Coaching Move Prepare Three to Five Calibrated Questions
Design open-ended calibrated questions using 'What' and 'How' to reveal the other party's underlying motivations, worries, and hopes—not just their stated positions. Prepare questions that expose value, identify deal killers, and push them to see your perspective. Effective calibrated questions make the other party work to justify their position and defend the status quo.
When to use: When a user is designing their discovery strategy or wants to move beyond positional bargaining.
preparationinformation_gatheringcommunication
Framework Universal Calibrated Questions
Six 'What' and 'How' questions that apply across nearly every negotiation: 'What are we trying to accomplish?'; 'How is that worthwhile?'; 'What's the core issue here?'; 'How does that affect things?'; 'What's the biggest challenge you face?'; 'How does this fit into what the objective is?' These force the other party to articulate motivation and justify priorities without you proposing solutions.
When to use: When a user is preparing calibrated questions and needs proven templates to adapt to their specific negotiation.
preparationinformation_gatheringcommunication
Framework Behind-the-Table Deal Killer Questions
When committee approval or internal stakeholder buy-in is required, use questions to identify hidden resistance: 'How does this affect the rest of your team?'; 'How on board are the people not on this call?'; 'What do your colleagues see as their main challenges in this area?' These expose whether your counterpart has real authority or if hidden stakeholders will kill the deal during implementation.
When to use: When a user is negotiating with a representative who must get approval from others or when implementation requires committee support.
preparationinformation_gatheringteam_negotiationpower_dynamics
Framework Deal-Killing Issue Discovery Questions
Six questions designed to unearth non-financial barriers to agreement: 'What are we up against here?'; 'What is the biggest challenge you face?'; 'How does making a deal with us affect things?'; 'What happens if you do nothing?'; 'What does doing nothing cost you?'; 'How does making this deal resonate with what your company prides itself on?' Ask these in clusters of two or three to allow the other party to examine the same issue from multiple angles.
When to use: When a user suspects the negotiation is stalled on non-monetary issues or hidden organizational concerns.
preparationinformation_gatheringleveragecommunication
Coaching Move Address Status and Self-Esteem Over Money
Recognize that many negotiations hinge on issues outside dollars and cents—self-esteem, status, autonomy, and nonfinancial needs. When someone internally opposes change because it threatens their review or makes them look bad, offer solutions that preserve their status rather than reducing price. Example: Instead of lowering price on accounting software, guarantee 90-day installation before their annual review to help them look good.
When to use: When a user hits unexpected resistance despite offering financial concessions, or when they sense the counterpart cares about intangibles.
preparationinformation_gatheringleverageemotionspower_dynamics
Quote Loss Aversion Mathematics
"A loss stings at least twice as much as an equivalent gain." This principle explains why addressing the other party's perceived losses (status, autonomy, stability) is often more effective than adding financial incentives. Removing a pain point is worth more to them than gaining an equivalent benefit.
When to use: When a user is deciding between offering more money versus offering non-monetary solutions to overcome resistance.
preparationleverageemotionspower_dynamics
Coaching Move Deploy Follow-Up Labels on Calibrated Responses
After asking calibrated questions, prepare follow-up labels to quickly reflect the other party's answers back to them. Use templates like 'It seems like __________ is important'; 'It seems you feel like my company is in a unique position to __________'; 'It seems like you are worried that __________.' This keeps them talking, revealing expanding information, and validates their concerns without committing to concessions.
When to use: When a user wants to maintain information flow and show empathy without immediately proposing solutions.
preparationinformation_gatheringcommunicationemotions
Coaching Move Prepare Noncash Offer List
Brainstorm items of value you can offer that cost the other party little but are valuable to them. Ask: 'What could they give that would almost get us to do it for free?' Create a prepared list of noncash offerings (publicity, introductions, resources, timeline flexibility, etc.) so you can propose creative trade-offs that don't deplete your budget while moving toward agreement.
When to use: When a user is budget-constrained or looking to create value beyond price concessions.

Example Lawyers Association Magazine Cover Story Trade
When negotiating speaking fees with a lawyers' association, Voss discovered the counterpart wanted to minimize cash payment to look good to his board. Instead of discounting, they structured a deal where the association paid partly through a cover story feature in their magazine. This was low-cost for them, advanced Voss's marketing interests, and solved their budget constraint—a noncash solution that satisfied both parties better than a price reduction.
When to use: When a user is stuck on price and needs an example of how noncash offers can unlock creative agreement.

Quote Relentless Curiosity About Motivation
"Great negotiators get past these blinders by being relentlessly curious about what is really motivating the other side." This emphasizes that effective negotiators move beyond stated positions to investigate underlying motivations, worries, and aspirations. Curiosity, not pushback, is the tool for discovering true value.
When to use: When a user is tempted to debate the other party's stated position rather than exploring their motivation.
information_gatheringcommunicationpower_dynamics
Quote Accept Other Party's Reality
J.K. Rowling quote cited by Voss: "You must accept the reality of other people. You think that reality is up for negotiation, that we think it's whatever you say it is. You must accept that we are as real as you are; you must accept that you are not God." This philosophical grounding reminds negotiators that the other party's worldview, concerns, and constraints are objectively real to them and cannot be negotiated away—only understood and navigated.
When to use: When a user is struggling with empathy or dismissing the other party's constraints as invalid or unreasonable.

Framework ROI of Preparation: 7:1 Return
Based on Black Swan Group experience, good initial preparation yields at least a 7:1 rate of return on time invested—measured in time saved renegotiating deals or clarifying implementation. This quantifies the business case for systematic one-sheet preparation: the hours invested upfront prevent costly rework and confusion later.
When to use: When a user is hesitant about investing time in preparation or wants justification for a thorough prep process.
preparation
Coaching Move Avoid Over-Scripting and Preordained Outcomes
Do not prepare detailed scripts or preordained agreements for exactly how the negotiation will unfold. Over-scripting reduces agility, creativity, and responsiveness to new information. It also makes you vulnerable to counterparts who adapt. The one sheet is a tool kit of tactics, not a predetermined playbook—flexibility and discovery remain more valuable than perfect predictive planning.
When to use: When a user is tempted to over-prepare with rigid scripts or predetermined deal terms.
preparationcreativitycommunication
Coaching Move Four-Step Goal Commitment Process
To maximize goal commitment and execution: (1) Set an optimistic but reasonable goal and define it clearly; (2) Write it down; (3) Discuss your goal with a colleague, which makes it harder to abandon under pressure; (4) Carry the written goal into the negotiation as your psychological anchor. This four-step process leverages commitment and social accountability.
When to use: When a user needs a tactical way to strengthen their goal-setting discipline and resist negotiation pressure to lower expectations.
